The storm is forecast to remain a hurricane until it makes landfall "}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Kingston, Jamaica"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Jamaica"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 78}, {"uri": "dmoz/Health/Public_Health_and_Safety/Tropical_Health", "label": "dmoz/Health/Public Health and Safety/Tropical Health", "wgt": 98}, {"uri": "news/Environment", "label": "news/Environment", "wgt": 67}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 255}, "sentiment": -0.1372549019607843, "breakingScore": 0.4518442558489666}
{"uri": "8209934873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "17:18:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T17:18:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T17:18:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.inquirer.com/weather/hurricane-beryl-jamaica-southern-caribbean-deaths-damage-20240704.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl roars by Jamaica after killing at least 7 people in the southeast Caribbean", "body": "KINGSTON, Jamaica -- Hurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least seven people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica.\"\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\n\" READ MORE: Beryl, the season's first hurricane, forms -- and sets a record\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\nBy evening, he said that Jamaica has not seen the \"worst of what could possibly happen.\"\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said.\n\nSeveral roadways in the country's interior settlements were impacted by fallen trees and utility poles, while some communities in the northern section were without electricity, according to the government's information service.\n\n\" READ MORE: Record-setting Hurricane Beryl's peak winds reach 165 mph, a Category 5 and a 'warning shot' for the season\n\nKingston resident Pauline Lynch said that she had stockpiled food and water in anticipation of the storm's arrival. With wind already driving rain, Lynch said, \"I have no control over what is coming so I just have to pray that all people of Jamaica is safe and we don't suffer no deaths, no loss.\"\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nPorter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.\"\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac, and the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun. Beryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula late Thursday or Friday, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Beryl. Holness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days.\n\nAn evacuation order was in place for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast, meanwhile was preparing for Beryl.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defense agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico. Laura Vel\u00e1zquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto. Because the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mexican government officials moved sea turtle eggs off Cancun beaches in an attempt to protect them from storm surge.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and reemerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico. Vel\u00e1zquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nLate Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4. Late Wednesday night, the storm's center was about 560 miles (905 kilometers) east-southeast of Tulum, Mexico. It had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 21 mph (32 kph). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the center.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane center director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to 6 or 9 feet (1.8 to 2.7 meters) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nHeavy rains of 4 to 8 inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island, he said.\n\nAs Beryl barreled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in southeastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nMichelle Forbes, the St. Vincent and Grenadines director of the National Emergency Management Organization, said that about 95% of homes in Mayreau and Union Island have been damaged by Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. Three other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality.\"\n\nSt. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has promised to rebuild the archipelago.\n\nThe last strong hurricane to hit the southeast Caribbean was Hurricane Ivan 20 years ago, which killed dozens of people in Grenada.", "source": {"uri": "inquirer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Philadelphia Inquirer"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-410622134", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "00:47:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T00:47:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T00:25:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/hurricane-beryl-roars-by-jamaica-after-killing-at-least-7-people-in-the-southeast-caribbean/article_07fc6a4a-c78b-5e09-a107-ca80fa0751ac.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl roars by Jamaica after killing at least 7 people in the southeast Caribbean", "body": "KINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) -- Hurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least seven people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica.\"\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\nBy evening, he said that Jamaica has not seen the \"worst of what could possibly happen.\"\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said.\n\nSeveral roadways in the country's interior settlements were impacted by fallen trees and utility poles, while some communities in the northern section were without electricity, according to the government's information service.\n\nBefore Beryl's arrival in Kingston, people had earlier boarded up windows, fishermen pulled their boats out of the water and workers dismantled roadside advertising boards to protect them from the lashing winds.\n\nKingston resident Pauline Lynch said that she had stockpiled food and water in anticipation of the storm's arrival. With wind already driving rain, Lynch said, \"I have no control over what is coming so I just have to pray that all people of Jamaica is safe and we don't suffer no deaths, no loss.\"\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nPorter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.\"\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac. Beryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near or over Jamaica on Wednesday, near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula on Friday, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Hurricane Beryl.\n\nHolness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days. He also announced an island-wide curfew between 6 a.m. and 6 p.m. on Wednesday.\n\nAn evacuation order was in place for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nA hurricane watch was in effect for Haiti's southern coast and the Yucatan's east coast. Belize issued a tropical storm watch stretching south from its border with Mexico to Belize City.\n\nLate Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4. On Wednesday, the storm's center was about 100 miles (160 kilometers) west of Kingston. It had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 20 mph (31 kph). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the center.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane center director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to 6 or 9 feet (1.8 to 2.7 meters) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nHeavy rains of 4 to 8 inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island, he said.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast was preparing for Beryl Wednesday. The government issued a hurricane warning for the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defense agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico. Laura Vel\u00e1zquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall between late Thursday and early Friday along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto. Because the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mexican government officials moved sea turtle eggs off Cancun beaches in an attempt to protect them from storm surge.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and reemerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico. Vel\u00e1zquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nAs Beryl barreled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in southeastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nMichelle Forbes, the St. Vincent and Grenadines director of the National Emergency Management Organization, said that about 95% of homes in Mayreau and Union Island have been damaged by Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. Three other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality.\"\n\nSt. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has promised to rebuild the archipelago.\n\nThe last strong hurricane to hit the southeast Caribbean was Hurricane Ivan 20 years ago, which killed dozens of people in Grenada.\n\nAssociated Press writers Mark Stevenson in Mexico City, Coral Murphy Marcos in San Juan, Puerto Rico and Lucanus Ollivierre in Kingstown, St. Vincent and Grenadines contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@register-herald.com", "name": {"uri": "8208704844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "01:56:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T01:56:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T01:55:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/hurricane-beryl-roars-by-jamaica-after-killing-at-least-7-people-in-the-southeast-caribbean/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl roars by Jamaica after killing at least 7 people in the southeast Caribbean - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "KINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) -- Hurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least seven people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica.\"\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\nBy evening, he said that Jamaica has not seen the \"worst of what could possibly happen.\"\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said.\n\nSeveral roadways in the country's interior settlements were impacted by fallen trees and utility poles, while some communities in the northern section were without electricity, according to the government's information service.\n\nKingston resident Pauline Lynch said that she had stockpiled food and water in anticipation of the storm's arrival. With wind already driving rain, Lynch said, \"I have no control over what is coming so I just have to pray that all people of Jamaica is safe and we don't suffer no deaths, no loss.\"\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nPorter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.\"\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac, and the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun. Beryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula late Thursday or Friday, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Beryl. Holness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days.\n\nAn evacuation order was in place for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast, meanwhile was preparing for Beryl.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defense agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico. Laura Vel\u00e1zquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto. Because the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mexican government officials moved sea turtle eggs off Cancun beaches in an attempt to protect them from storm surge.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and reemerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico. Vel\u00e1zquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nLate Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4. On Wednesday, the storm's center was about 100 miles (160 kilometers) west of Kingston. It had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 20 mph (31 kph). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the center.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane center director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to 6 or 9 feet (1.8 to 2.7 meters) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nHeavy rains of 4 to 8 inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island, he said.\n\nAs Beryl barreled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in southeastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nMichelle Forbes, the St. Vincent and Grenadines director of the National Emergency Management Organization, said that about 95% of homes in Mayreau and Union Island have been damaged by Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. Three other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality.\"\n\nSt. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has promised to rebuild the archipelago.\n\nThe last strong hurricane to hit the southeast Caribbean was Hurricane Ivan 20 years ago, which killed dozens of people in Grenada.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "wgt": 70}], "image": "https://wsvn.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2024/07/240703-Hurricane-Beryl-roars-toward-Jamaica-after-killing-at-least-6-people-in-the-southeast-Caribbean.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9704864", "eventUri": "eng-9704864", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Kingston, Jamaica"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Jamaica"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.003921568627450966, "wgt": 210, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8208703789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "01:56:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T01:56:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T01:54:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/hurricane-beryl-roars-by-jamaica-after-killing-at-least-7-people-in-the-southeast-caribbean/article_ec5a3fff-fb38-5684-ad08-aff172edc8ca.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl roars by Jamaica after killing at least 7 people in the southeast Caribbean", "body": "Workers remove an advertisement from a billboard for protection ahead of Hurricane Beryl's expected arrival, in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, Wednesday, July 3, 2024.\n\nKINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) -- Hurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least seven people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica.\"\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\nBy evening, he said that Jamaica has not seen the \"worst of what could possibly happen.\"\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said.\n\nSeveral roadways in the country's interior settlements were impacted by fallen trees and utility poles, while some communities in the northern section were without electricity, according to the government's information service.\n\nKingston resident Pauline Lynch said that she had stockpiled food and water in anticipation of the storm's arrival. With wind already driving rain, Lynch said, \"I have no control over what is coming so I just have to pray that all people of Jamaica is safe and we don't suffer no deaths, no loss.\"\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nPorter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.\"\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac, and the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun. Beryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula late Thursday or Friday, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Beryl. Holness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days.\n\nAn evacuation order was in place for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast, meanwhile was preparing for Beryl.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defense agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico. Laura Vel\u00e1zquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto. Because the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mexican government officials moved sea turtle eggs off Cancun beaches in an attempt to protect them from storm surge.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and reemerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico. Vel\u00e1zquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nLate Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4. On Wednesday, the storm's center was about 100 miles (160 kilometers) west of Kingston. It had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 20 mph (31 kph). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the center.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane center director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to 6 or 9 feet (1.8 to 2.7 meters) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nHeavy rains of 4 to 8 inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island, he said.\n\nAs Beryl barreled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in southeastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nMichelle Forbes, the St. Vincent and Grenadines director of the National Emergency Management Organization, said that about 95% of homes in Mayreau and Union Island have been damaged by Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. Three other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality.\"\n\nSt. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has promised to rebuild the archipelago.\n\nThe last strong hurricane to hit the southeast Caribbean was Hurricane Ivan 20 years ago, which killed dozens of people in Grenada.\n\nAssociated Press writers Mark Stevenson in Mexico City, Coral Murphy Marcos in San Juan, Puerto Rico and Lucanus Ollivierre in Kingstown, St. Vincent and Grenadines contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@eagletribune.com", "name": "Associated Press", Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nPrime minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\nBy evening, he said that Jamaica has not seen the \"worst of what could possibly happen\".\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Mr Holness said.\n\nSeveral roadways in the country's interior settlements were impacted by fallen trees and utility poles, while some communities in the northern section were without electricity, according to the government's information service.\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nMr Porter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades\".\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac, and the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun.\n\nBeryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula late on Thursday or Friday, according to the US National Hurricane Centre.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Beryl. Mr Holness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days.\n\nAn evacuation order was in place for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Mr Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast, meanwhile was preparing for Beryl.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defence agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico.\n\nLaura Velazquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto.\n\nBecause the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mexican government officials moved sea turtle eggs off Cancun beaches in an attempt to protect them from storm surge.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and re-emerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nMs Velazquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nLate on Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4.\n\nLate on Wednesday night, the storm's centre was about 560 miles (905 kilometres) east-southeast of Tulum, Mexico. It had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 21 mph (32 kph). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the centre.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane centre director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day on Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to six or nine feet (1.8 to 2.7 metres) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nHeavy rains of four to eight inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island.\n\nAs Beryl barrelled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in south-eastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nMichelle Forbes, the St Vincent and Grenadines director of the National Emergency Management Organisation, said that about 95% of homes in Mayreau and Union Island have been damaged by Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said.\n\nThree other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. {"uri": "8208628030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "00:12:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T00:12:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T00:12:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/climate-and-environment/hurricane-beryl-roars-by-jamaica-after-killing-at-least-6-people-in-the-southeast-caribbean-1.6949314", "title": "Hurricane Beryl roars by Jamaica after killing at least 6 people in the southeast Caribbean", "body": "Hurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least six people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica.\"\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\n\"We are placing emphasis on ensuring they are comfortable and well looked after,\" he said in a social media post.\n\nBefore Beryl's arrival in Kingston, people had earlier boarded up windows, fishermen pulled their boats out of the water and workers dismantled roadside advertising boards to protect them from the lashing winds.\n\nKingston resident Pauline Lynch said that she had stockpiled food and water in anticipation of the storm's arrival. With wind already driving rain, Lynch said, \"I have no control over what is coming so I just have to pray that all people of Jamaica is safe and we don't suffer no deaths, no loss.\"\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nPorter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.\"\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac. Beryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near or over Jamaica on Wednesday, near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula on Friday, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Hurricane Beryl.\n\nHolness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days. He also announced an island-wide curfew between 6 a.m. and 6 p.m. on Wednesday.\n\nSecurity forces \"will be fully mobilized to maintain public order and assist with disaster relief. As soon as the hurricane has passed, the security forces have developed strategic plans to counter any potential threat of looting or any other opportunistic crimes,\" Holness warned.\n\nAn evacuation order was also issued for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nA hurricane watch was in effect for Haiti's southern coast and the Yucatan's east coast. Belize issued a tropical storm watch stretching south from its border with Mexico to Belize City.\n\nLate Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 km/h) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4. On Wednesday, the storm's center was about 65 miles (100 kilometres) west-southwest of Kingston. It had maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 km/h) and was moving west-northwest at 20 mph (31 km/h). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the center.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane center director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to 6 or 9 feet (1.8 to 2.7 metres) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nWidespread damage caused by Hurricane Beryl on Union Island in St. Vincent and the Grenadines is seen in this image taken from video on July 2, 2024.\n\nHeavy rains of 4 to 8 inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island, he said.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast was preparing for Beryl Wednesday. The government issued a hurricane warning for the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defence agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico. Laura Velazquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall between late Thursday and early Friday along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto. Because the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and reemerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico. Velazquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nAs Beryl barrelled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in southeastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nThis picture taken by U.S. astronaut Matthew Dominick shows the scale of Hurricane Beryl as the International Space Station orbited over the Caribbean on July 1, 2024. (Source @dominickmatthew via X)\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. Two other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press. She said Carriacou and Petit Martinique sustained the greatest damage, with scores of homes and businesses flattened in Carriacou.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality.\"\n\nSt. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has promised to rebuild the archipelago. He noted that 90% of homes on Union Island were destroyed, and that \"similar levels of devastation\" were expected on the islands of Myreau and Canouan.\n\nThe last strong hurricane to hit the southeast Caribbean was Hurricane Ivan 20 years ago, which killed dozens of people in Grenada.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8208655760", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "00:49:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T00:49:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T00:49:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.wccbcharlotte.com/2024/07/03/hurricane-beryl-roars-by-jamaica-after-killing-at-least-7-people-in-the-southeast-caribbean/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl Roars By Jamaica After Killing At Least 7 People In The Southeast Caribbean - WCCB Charlotte's CW", "body": "KINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) -- Hurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least seven people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica.\"\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\nBy evening, he said that Jamaica has not seen the \"worst of what could possibly happen.\"\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said.\n\nSeveral roadways in the country's interior settlements were impacted by fallen trees and utility poles, while some communities in the northern section were without electricity, according to the government's information service.\n\nBefore Beryl's arrival in Kingston, people had earlier boarded up windows, fishermen pulled their boats out of the water and workers dismantled roadside advertising boards to protect them from the lashing winds.\n\nKingston resident Pauline Lynch said that she had stockpiled food and water in anticipation of the storm's arrival. With wind already driving rain, Lynch said, \"I have no control over what is coming so I just have to pray that all people of Jamaica is safe and we don't suffer no deaths, no loss.\"\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nPorter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.\"\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac. Beryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near or over Jamaica on Wednesday, near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula on Friday, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThis image provided by NASA shows Hurricane Beryl from the International Space Station on Sunday, July 1, 2024. Beryl was roaring toward Jamaica on Wednesday, July 3, with islanders scrambling to make preparations after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least six people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean. (NASA via AP)\n\nHolness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days. He also announced an island-wide curfew between 6 a.m. and 6 p.m. on Wednesday.\n\nAn evacuation order was in place for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nA hurricane watch was in effect for Haiti's southern coast and the Yucatan's east coast. Belize issued a tropical storm watch stretching south from its border with Mexico to Belize City.\n\nLate Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4. On Wednesday, the storm's center was about 100 miles (160 kilometers) west of Kingston. It had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 20 mph (31 kph). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the center.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane center director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to 6 or 9 feet (1.8 to 2.7 meters) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nHeavy rains of 4 to 8 inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island, he said.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast was preparing for Beryl Wednesday. The government issued a hurricane warning for the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defense agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico. Laura Vel\u00e1zquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall between late Thursday and early Friday along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto. Because the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mexican government officials moved sea turtle eggs off Cancun beaches in an attempt to protect them from storm surge.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and reemerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico. Vel\u00e1zquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nAs Beryl barreled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in southeastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nMichelle Forbes, the St. Vincent and Grenadines director of the National Emergency Management Organization, said that about 95% of homes in Mayreau and Union Island have been damaged by Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. Three other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality.\"\n\nSt. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has promised to rebuild the archipelago.\n\nThe last strong hurricane to hit the southeast Caribbean was Hurricane Ivan 20 years ago, which killed dozens of people in Grenada.\n\nFacebookTwitterPinterestLinkedin", "source": {"uri": "wccbcharlotte.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WCCB Charlotte's CW"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-410577782", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "23:08:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T23:08:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T16:53:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.kurv.com/hurricane-beryl-roars-by-jamaica-after-killing-at-least-6-people-in-the-southeast-caribbean/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl Roars By Jamaica After Killing At Least 6 People In The Southeast Caribbean", "body": "This image provided by NASA shows Hurricane Beryl from the International Space Station on Sunday, July 1, 2024. Beryl was roaring toward Jamaica on Wednesday, July 3, with islanders scrambling to make preparations after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least six people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean. (NASA via AP)\n\n(AP) -- Hurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least six people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica.\"\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\n\"We are placing emphasis on ensuring they are comfortable and well looked after,\" he said in a social media post.\n\nBefore Beryl's arrival in Kingston, people had earlier boarded up windows, fishermen pulled their boats out of the water and workers dismantled roadside advertising boards to protect them from the lashing winds.\n\nKingston resident Pauline Lynch said that she had stockpiled food and water in anticipation of the storm's arrival. With wind already driving rain, Lynch said, \"I have no control over what is coming so I just have to pray that all people of Jamaica is safe and we don't suffer no deaths, no loss.\"\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nPorter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.\"\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac. Beryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near or over Jamaica on Wednesday, near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula on Friday, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Hurricane Beryl.\n\nHolness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days. He also announced an island-wide curfew between 6 a.m. and 6 p.m. on Wednesday.\n\nSecurity forces \"will be fully mobilized to maintain public order and assist with disaster relief. As soon as the hurricane has passed, the security forces have developed strategic plans to counter any potential threat of looting or any other opportunistic crimes,\" Holness warned.\n\nAn evacuation order was also issued for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nA hurricane watch was in effect for Haiti's southern coast and the Yucatan's east coast. Belize issued a tropical storm watch stretching south from its border with Mexico to Belize City.\n\nLate Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4. On Wednesday, the storm's center was about 65 miles (100 kilometers) west-southwest of Kingston. It had maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 20 mph (31 kph). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the center.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane center director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to 6 or 9 feet (1.8 to 2.7 meters) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nHeavy rains of 4 to 8 inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island, he said.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast was preparing for Beryl Wednesday. The government issued a hurricane warning for the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defense agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico. Laura Vel\u00e1zquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall between late Thursday and early Friday along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto. Because the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and reemerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico. Vel\u00e1zquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nAs Beryl barreled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in southeastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. Two other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press. She said Carriacou and Petit Martinique sustained the greatest damage, with scores of homes and businesses flattened in Carriacou.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality.\"\n\nSt. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has promised to rebuild the archipelago. He noted that 90% of homes on Union Island were destroyed.\n\nThe last strong hurricane to hit the southeast Caribbean was Hurricane Ivan 20 years ago, which killed dozens of people in Grenada.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Mark Stevenson in Mexico City and Coral Murphy Marcos in San Juan, Puerto Rico, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "kurv.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8208858557", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "04:44:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T04:44:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T04:44:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/hurricane-beryl-roars-by-jamaica-after-killing-at-least-seven-people-1645693.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl roars by Jamaica after killing at least seven people | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Hurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica on Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least seven people and caused significant damage in the south-east Caribbean.\n\nThe US National Hurricane Centre said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica\".\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nPrime minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\nBy evening, he said that Jamaica has not seen the \"worst of what could possibly happen\".\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Mr Holness said.\n\nSeveral roadways in the country's interior settlements were impacted by fallen trees and utility poles, while some communities in the northern section were without electricity, according to the government's information service.\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nMr Porter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades\".\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac, and the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun.\n\nBeryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula late on Thursday or Friday, according to the US National Hurricane Centre.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Beryl. Mr Holness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days.\n\nAn evacuation order was in place for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Mr Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast, meanwhile was preparing for Beryl.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defence agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico.\n\nLaura Velazquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto.\n\nBecause the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mexican government officials moved sea turtle eggs off Cancun beaches in an attempt to protect them from storm surge.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and re-emerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nMs Velazquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nLate on Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4.\n\nLate on Wednesday night, the storm's centre was about 560 miles (905 kilometres) east-southeast of Tulum, Mexico. It had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 21 mph (32 kph). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the centre.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane centre director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day on Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to six or nine feet (1.8 to 2.7 metres) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nHeavy rains of four to eight inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island.\n\nAs Beryl barrelled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in south-eastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nMichelle Forbes, the St Vincent and Grenadines director of the National Emergency Management Organisation, said that about 95% of homes in Mayreau and Union Island have been damaged by Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said.\n\nThree other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said on Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality\".", "source": It had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 21 mph (32 kph). "news/Environment", "wgt": 57}], "image": "https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2024/07/04/05/wire-86907693-1720067212-318_636x382.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9704864", "eventUri": "eng-9704864", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1058823529411764, "wgt": 206, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-410597232", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "23:52:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T23:52:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T21:12:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/hurricane-beryl-roars-by-jamaica-after-killing-at-least-6-people-in-the-southeast-caribbean/article_07fc6a4a-c78b-5e09-a107-ca80fa0751ac.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl roars by Jamaica after killing at least 6 people in the southeast Caribbean", "body": "KINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) -- Hurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful Category 4 storm earlier killed at least six people and caused significant damage in the southeast Caribbean.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica.\"\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\n\"We are placing emphasis on ensuring they are comfortable and well looked after,\" he said in a social media post.\n\nBefore Beryl's arrival in Kingston, people had earlier boarded up windows, fishermen pulled their boats out of the water and workers dismantled roadside advertising boards to protect them from the lashing winds.\n\nKingston resident Pauline Lynch said that she had stockpiled food and water in anticipation of the storm's arrival. With wind already driving rain, Lynch said, \"I have no control over what is coming so I just have to pray that all people of Jamaica is safe and we don't suffer no deaths, no loss.\"\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\n\"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nPorter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.\"\n\nA hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac. Beryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near or over Jamaica on Wednesday, near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula on Friday, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Hurricane Beryl.\n\nHolness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days. He also announced an island-wide curfew between 6 a.m. and 6 p.m. on Wednesday.\n\nSecurity forces \"will be fully mobilized to maintain public order and assist with disaster relief. As soon as the hurricane has passed, the security forces have developed strategic plans to counter any potential threat of looting or any other opportunistic crimes,\" Holness warned.\n\nAn evacuation order was also issued for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nA hurricane watch was in effect for Haiti's southern coast and the Yucatan's east coast. Belize issued a tropical storm watch stretching south from its border with Mexico to Belize City.\n\nLate Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4. On Wednesday, the storm's center was about 65 miles (100 kilometers) west-southwest of Kingston. It had maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 20 mph (31 kph). Hurricane strength winds extended 45 miles from the center.\n\nIn Miami, hurricane center director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight.\n\nJamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to 6 or 9 feet (1.8 to 2.7 meters) above normal tide levels in some area.\n\nHeavy rains of 4 to 8 inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island, he said.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast was preparing for Beryl Wednesday. The government issued a hurricane warning for the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun.\n\nThe head of Mexico's civil defense agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico. Laura Vel\u00e1zquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall between late Thursday and early Friday along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto. Because the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nThe hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and reemerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico. Vel\u00e1zquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nAs Beryl barreled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in southeastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. Two other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press. She said Carriacou and Petit Martinique sustained the greatest damage, with scores of homes and businesses flattened in Carriacou.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality.\"\n\nSt. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has promised to rebuild the archipelago. He noted that 90% of homes on Union Island were destroyed.\n\nThe last strong hurricane to hit the southeast Caribbean was Hurricane Ivan 20 years ago, which killed dozens of people in Grenada.\n\nAssociated Press writers Mark Stevenson in Mexico City and Coral Murphy Marcos in San Juan, Puerto Rico, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8209259112", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "09:36:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T09:36:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T09:36:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/hurricane-beryl-arrives-on-jamaica-s-shores-after-7-killed-in-southeast-caribbean-heavy-rains-winds-latest-updates-2024-07-04-940248", "title": "Hurricane Beryl arrives on Jamaica's shores after 7 killed in southeast Caribbean", "body": "Kingston: The 'potentially catastrophic' Hurricane Beryl arrived on the shores of Jamaica after claiming the lives of at least seven people in the southeast Caribbean in the form of fierce winds and heavy rains, while causing significant damage. The US National Hurricane Centre said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica.\"\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital. Prime Minister Andrew Holness said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters.\n\nBy evening, he said that Jamaica has not seen the \"worst of what could possibly happen.\" \"We can do as much as we can do, as humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said. Several roadways in the country's interior settlements were impacted by fallen trees and utility poles, while some communities in the northern section were without electricity, according to the government's information service.\n\nKingston resident Pauline Lynch said that she had stockpiled food and water in anticipation of the storm's arrival. With wind already driving rain, Lynch said, \"I have no control over what is coming so I just have to pray that all people of Jamaica is safe and we don't suffer no deaths, no loss.\"\n\nBy midday, winds already howled in the capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast. \"We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" including storm surge, high winds and flash flooding, said Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather.\n\nPorter called Beryl \"the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.\" A hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac, and the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun.\n\nBeryl was forecast to weaken slightly over the next day or two, but still be at or near major-hurricane strength when it passes near the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula late Thursday or Friday, according to the US National Hurricane Centre.\n\nJamaica was under a state of emergency as the island was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact of Beryl. Holness said that the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days. An evacuation order was in place for communities across Jamaica that are prone to flooding and landslides. Holness urged Jamaicans to move away from low-lying areas.\n\nMexico's Caribbean coast, meanwhile was preparing for Beryl. The head of Mexico's civil defence agency said that Beryl is expected to make a rare double strike on Mexico. Laura Vel\u00e1zquez said the hurricane is expected to make landfall along a relatively unpopulated stretch of the Caribbean coast between Tulum and the inland town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto. Because the coast there is largely made up of lagoons and mangroves, there are few resorts or hotels in the area south of Tulum.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mexican government officials moved sea turtle eggs off Cancun beaches in an attempt to protect them from storm surge. The hurricane is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it crosses the Yucatan peninsula and reemerge over the weekend at storm strength into the Gulf of Mexico. Vel\u00e1zquez said that Beryl is then expected to hit Mexican territory a second time in the Gulf coast states of Veracruz or Tamaulipas, near the Texas border.\n\nLate Monday, Beryl became the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph (270 kph) Tuesday before weakening to a still-destructive Category 4. Late Wednesday night, the storm's centre was about 560 miles (905 kilometres) east-southeast of Tulum, Mexico. It had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) and was moving west-northwest at 21 mph (32 kph).\n\nIn Miami, hurricane centre director Michael Brennan in an online briefing said people on the island should plan to stay sheltered throughout the day Wednesday with conditions only beginning to improve overnight. Jamaica's southern coast, where Kingston is located, was expected to bear the brunt of Beryl with coastal water levels rising to 6 or 9 feet (1.8 to 2.7 meters) above normal tide levels in some areas.\n\nHeavy rains of 4 to 8 inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island, he said. As Beryl barreled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in southeastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada. Michelle Forbes, the St. Vincent and Grenadines director of the National Emergency Management Organization, said that about 95% of homes in Mayreau and Union Island have been damaged by Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. Three other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nOne fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told The Associated Press. Grenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality.\"\n\nSt. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has promised to rebuild the archipelago. "dmoz/Health/Public_Health_and_Safety/Tropical_Health", "label": "dmoz/Health/Public Health and Safety/Tropical Health", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Environment", "label": "news/Environment", "wgt": 65}], "image": "https://resize.indiatvnews.com/en/resize/newbucket/1200_-/2024/07/hurricane-beryl-1720085662.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9704864", "eventUri": "eng-9704864",
