{"uri": "8209506693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "12:11:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T12:11:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T12:10:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/hurricane-beryl-heads-for-cayman-islands,-mexico-after-striking-jamaica/82688260", "title": "Hurricane Beryl heads for Cayman Islands, Mexico after striking Jamaica", "body": "KINGSTON (Reuters) - Hurricane Beryl rumbled towards the Cayman Islands and Mexico on Thursday, after pummeling Jamaica with winds and rain that caused floods and widespread power outages and leaving at a deadly trail of destruction in several smaller Caribbean islands.\n\nBeryl has so far left at least 10 people dead but that number was widely expected to rise as communications are restored on islands devastated by flooding and powerful winds.\n\nBeryl's eyewall skirted Jamaica's southern coast, pummeling communities as a powerful Category 4 storm on the five-step Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, as emergency workers evacuated people from flood-prone areas.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nBeryl moved away from Jamaica early on Thursday. At around 0900 GMT, the hurricane, now a Category 3 storm, was 55 miles (90 km) from Grand Cayman and about 440 miles (700 km) off Tulum, Mexico, the U.S. National Hurricane Center said.\n\nBeryl was carrying top winds of 130 mph (209 kph), and was expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands, where life-threatening surf and rip currents were possible, the NHC said.\n\nA hurricane warning was in force for the Cayman Islands east coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.\n\nMexico's tourist centres of Cancun and the wider Yucatan peninsula lie in Beryl's predicted path. Cancun's airport was thronged with tourists hoping to catch last flights out before the storm arrives. Workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection.\n\nMexico's defense ministry opened around 120 storm shelters, and asked visitors to heed instructions on evacuation or other measures.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and at its peak earlier this week was the earliest Category 5 storm on record. A Category 5 hurricane brings winds of 157 mph (252 kph) or higher, capable of causing catastrophic damage including the destruction of homes and infrastructure.\n\nJAMAICA AND SMALL ISLANDS\n\nIn Jamaica the island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a curfew for Wednesday, which was extended to Thursday as storm conditions continued. At least one person was reported killed in the storm.\n\nNearly 1,000 people were in shelters by Wednesday evening, Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency said in an interview on local news.\n\nThe storm hit St. Vincent and the Grenadines earlier in the week. Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves said in a radio interview that Union Island was \"flattened\" and it would \"be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nThere were at least three confirmed fatalities and crop damage was widespread, senior officials told Reuters. Union Island suffered destruction of more than 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions after the storm made impact earlier in the week, with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nVenezuelan President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died, four were missing, and over 8,000 homes damaged.\n\nThe U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year. The season runs from the start of June to the end of November\n\nBeryl's destructive power, coming so early in the hurricane season, underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather.", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": "SWI swissinfo.ch"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8208978281", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "06:28:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T06:28:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T06:27:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/hurricane-beryl-churns-towards-mexico-after-hammering-jamaica/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl churns towards Mexico after hammering Jamaica | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "Deadly Hurricane Beryl powered towards Mexico late Wednesday, after battering Jamaica's southern coast with devastating winds and sea surge.\n\nThe Category 4 storm has left a trail of destruction in its path across the Caribbean, killing at least seven people as it has strengthened rapidly.\n\nBeryl was pulling away from Jamaica late Wednesday and was expected to pass just south of the Cayman Islands overnight, before moving onward to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center (NHC) said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nMexican officials are scrambling to prepare, with Beryl expected to bring damaging winds, a dangerous storm surge and heavy rainfall over the Yucatan Peninsula and Belize.\n\n\"We will have intense rains and wind gusts\" from Thursday, Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for around 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo, where Beryl will likely hit.\n\nIn Jamaica, \"life-threatening flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall\" were still expected overnight, the NHC said.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power, according to the Jamaica Gleaner newspaper, citing a public service company.\n\nThe devastating hurricane-force winds, life-threatening storm surge, and damaging waves that continue to damage Jamaica are expected in the Cayman Islands overnight, when Beryl passes by while at or near major hurricane intensity.\n\nJamaica Prime Minister Andrew Holness had declared a curfew from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff had scrambled to be ready.\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment -- including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nAs of Wednesday night, Beryl was packing maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph), said the NHC.\n\n- 'No communication' -\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St Vincent and the Grenadines, said that it would take a \"herculean effort\" to rebuild after the substantial destruction and that \"90-odd percent of the houses were blown away\" on Union Island.\n\n\"Most of the country doesn't have electricity, and more than half without water at the moment,\" he said.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 13.5-square mile (35-square kilometer) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country's main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela's northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\n- Climate change -\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was damaged.\n\nbur-dw-bfm/dhw\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 28 Spokane"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ivan_shaw@fox28spokane.com", "name": They were expecting Beryl to produce rainfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches, with isolated totals of 12 inches, across Jamaica and the southwestern Haitian Peninsula through late Wednesday.\n\nBeryl made landfall on Grenada's Carriacou Island in the Caribbean Sea with maximum sustained winds of 150 mph around 11 a.m. Tuesday. It is the strongest known hurricane to pass through the Grenadines, according to data from NOAA since 1851.\n\nOn Sunday, Beryl became the earliest Category 4 hurricane on record in the Atlantic and the only Category 4 storm ever recorded in June.\n\nIt then later became the earliest Category 5 storm in history before being downgraded to a Category 4 storm on Tuesday.\n\nOnly seven named storms have formed over the last 173 years in this sector of the Atlantic before July 4, according to Accuweather.\n\nMeanwhile, Alberto, the first tropical storm of the season, made landfall over Mexico on June 20 and then pummeled Texas the next day with rain while Tropical Storm Chris, the third named storm of the season, made landfall in eastern Mexico late Sunday.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8209803990", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "15:35:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T15:35:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T15:34:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.tpr.org/2024-07-03/hurricane-beryl-blasts-past-jamaica-on-its-way-to-the-cayman-islands-and-mexico", "title": "Hurricane Beryl blasts past Jamaica on its way to the Cayman Islands and Mexico", "body": "Hurricane Beryl lashed Jamaica as a Category 4 storm overnight and is forecast to pass just south of the Cayman Islands on Thursday morning before reaching the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico on Friday.\n\nAt 8 a.m. EDT, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) said the center of Beryl was about 50 miles southwest of Grand Cayman and about 385 miles east-southeast of Tulum, Mexico. It was moving west-northwest at about 20 miles per hour.\n\nBeryl's maximum sustained winds decreased to 120 miles per hour overnight after being downgraded from a Category 5 on Tuesday. It killed at least seven people, slashed power, destroyed buildings and blocked roads as it tore through Grenada and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, according to The Associated Press.\n\n\"The good news is that Beryl has begun weakening a little bit,\" NHC Director Michael Brennan said in a late Tuesday video update. \"But those peak winds are only going to come down very slowly over the next couple of days, and we're still expecting Beryl to be a powerful major hurricane when it reaches Jamaica.\"\n\nThe NHC warned that Beryl could cause flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall in much of Jamaica and parts of Haiti, and that mountainous areas could experience \"destructive\" wind gusts.\n\nAll three of Jamaica's international airports were closed on Wednesday, and officials say the island's electricity and water service would likely beshut off as a precaution to prevent fires and protect equipment.\n\nJamaican Prime Minister Andrew Holness declared a \"major disaster area\" and implemented an island-wide curfew from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. local time, based on what he called the \"strength, path and potential threat\" posed by Beryl.\n\n\"This is to ensure the safety of everyone during the passage of the storm and prevent any movement with the intent to carry out criminal activity,\" Holness said in an Instagram video.\n\nJamaica's size -- at some 146 miles long and 51 miles at its widest point -- made it an unlikely target of a direct hit. Only two hurricanes have made landfall there in the last 40 years, CNN noted: Sandy in 2012 and Gilbert in 1988.\n\nThe NHC has a hurricane warning in place for all three of the Cayman Islands and for parts of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun, including Cozumel.\n\nWhile the storm is expected to weaken today and Friday, it's forecast to be near-major hurricane intensity today as it passed the Cayman Islands and would likely remain a hurricane until it makes landfall on the Yucatan Peninsula. Hurricane-force winds extended up to 45 miles from the center and tropical-storm-force winds extended up to 175 miles.\n\nBeryl is expected to drop four to six inches of rain, with localized amounts of 10 inches, today into Friday along the Yucatan Peninsula and scattered flash flooding is anticipated. Storm surge along the east coast of the peninsula could be as much as four to six feet above ground level in areas of onshore winds within the hurricane warning area.\n\nIn Jamaica, journalist Nick Davis, who is based in Kingston, told NPR's \"Morning Edition\" that trees and power lines were down and some 400,000 people were without power. There have been no reports of injuries or deaths as first responders assessed the damage after daybreak.\n\nBeryl wreaked havoc on several countries in the eastern Caribbean Sea. Photos emerging from the hardest-hit islands show roofs torn from buildings, fishing vessels ripped apart and roads flooded with water and sand.\n\nSome of the worst damage appears to have occurred in Carriacou and Petite Martinique, two small islands in Grenada.\n\nOfficials said about 98% of buildings on the islands -- which are home to some 6,000 people -- had been damaged or destroyed, including Carriacou's main health facility, according to the New York Times. Three storm-related fatalities have been confirmed there so far, per the AP.\n\n\"The possibility that there may be more fatalities remains a grim reality as movement is still highly restricted,\" Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said at a news conference on Tuesday.\n\nTwo other deaths have been reported in northern Venezuela's Sucre state, where authorities said another five people are unaccounted for and a total of 25,000 have been affected by heavy rains, winds and river flooding from the outer bands of the storm.\n\nVenezuela's Vice President Delcy Rodr\u00edguez was injured after being hit by a falling tree while visiting one of the affected towns, CNN reports.\n\nThe country of St. Vincent and the Grenadines was also hit hard, with Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves announcing at a press conference that 90% of the houses on Union Island -- which is about 3 miles long and home to some 3,000 people -- have been damaged or destroyed.\n\n\"The Union Island airport's roof is gone,\" Gonsalves said, per CBS News. \"It's no more.\"\n\nAs damage assessment and recovery efforts get underway, offers of help are also flooding in.\n\nPresident Biden said at a Tuesday news conference that \"people in impacted islands and communities are in our prayers, and we stand by to provide assistance to them.\"\n\nThe Washington, D.C.-based nonprofit World Central Kitchen also announced on Tuesday that it has teams mobilizing to distribute food -- starting with sandwiches -- to people in need across the region including in Antigua, Grenada, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines.\n\nAs Jamaicans hunker down for the storm, countries in the northwestern Caribbean Sea and western Gulf of Mexico are warned they could be next as Beryl moves west.\n\nThe NHC expects Beryl to continue moving west as a hurricane, albeit with some weakening possible over the next day or so.\n\nIt says tropical storm conditions are expected along the south coast of Hispaniola on Wednesday, and possible along the coast of Belize by Thursday or early Friday.\n\nHurricane conditions are possible along portions of the east coast of the Yucatan Peninsula as soon as late Thursday.\n\nIn the U.S., officials are urging residents of coastal Texas to \"keep an eye on the Gulf this holiday week.\"\n\nThe Texas Division of Emergency Management announced Tuesday that residents and visitors in coastal areas should heed local warnings and have a plan ready in case of bad weather, particularly over the weekend.\n\n\"While Texans take time to enjoy the holiday weekend with family and friends, it's important to stay weather aware, pay close attention to the rapidly-changing forecasts, and don't be caught without an emergency plan,\" said Texas Emergency Management Chief Nim Kidd.\n\nMeteorologist Eric Berger told Houston Public Media that while Beryl's potential impact on the central Texas coast is still uncertain, it's not likely to strike with the same intensity it's bringing to the Caribbean.\n\n\"My sense of what will happen is we will see enhanced rain chances Saturday and especially Sunday but I am not anticipating a hurricane to form in the Gulf and move into the central Texas coast,\" he added.\n\nBeryl is an unusually strong hurricane for this early in the season, fueled by record-high ocean temperatures that have been driven by climate change -- which is making powerful storms more common.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has predicted an extra active Atlantic hurricane season, which spans June through November.\n\nAs they prepare for Beryl, some Jamaican officials are pointing to the storm as an example of how developing countries bear the brunt of climate change.\n\nHolness, the prime minister, said in a televised speech Tuesday that as the earliest Category 5 hurricane on record, Beryl highlights the growing impact of climate change on Small Island Developing Stateslike Jamaica.\n\n\"While our carbon emissions are miniscule, our region bears the brunt of the impacts of climate change,\" he added. \"This hurricane further highlights the urgent need for global climate action and targeted support to enhance resilience against the escalating dangers of climate change.\"\n\nEchoing those remarks, Jamaican Senator Delroy Williams told CNN that the international community must do more to widen coastal cities' access to climate change-related funding and improve infrastructure in low-lying areas.\n\nBeryl made that conversation extra personal for Simon Stiell, the executive secretary of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and a native of Carriacou.\n\nHis late grandmother's home was destroyed, and his parents' property was damaged, his office told AFP. He called climate change \"not a tomorrow problem.\"", "source": {"uri": "tpr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Texas Public Radio"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8209306621", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:05:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:05:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:05:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/hurricane-beryl-powers-towards-mexico-cayman-islands-after-battering-jamaica-6032355", "title": "Hurricane Beryl Powers Towards Mexico, Cayman Islands After Battering Jamaica", "body": "Beryl weakened to a Category 3 storm overnight, sustaining winds of 125 miles (200 kilometres) an hour, but is forecast to be \"at or near major hurricane intensity\" while it passes by the Caymans, according to the US National Hurricane Center (NHC).\n\nThe storm has left a trail of destruction across the Caribbean, killing at least seven people\n\nKingston, Jamaica:\n\nHurricane Beryl powered towards Mexico and the Cayman Islands early Thursday, threatening strong winds and a storm surge after battering Jamaica's southern coast.\n\nBeryl weakened to a Category 3 storm overnight, sustaining winds of 125 miles (200 kilometres) an hour, but is forecast to be \"at or near major hurricane intensity\" while it passes by the Caymans, according to the US National Hurricane Center (NHC).\n\n\"Strong winds, dangerous storm surge and damaging winds\" were expected across the Cayman Islands overnight, the NHC said early Thursday.\n\nThe storm has left a trail of destruction across the Caribbean, killing at least seven people and bringing with it flash floods and mudslides as it moves towards Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nMexican officials have scrambled to prepare, with the NHC warning Beryl will remain a hurricane until it makes landfall on the Yucatan Peninsula.\n\n\"We will have intense rains and wind gusts\" from Thursday, Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for around 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo, where Beryl will likely hit.\n\nIn Jamaica, more than 400,000 people were without power, according to the Jamaica Gleaner newspaper, citing a public service company.\n\nJamaica Prime Minister Andrew Holness had declared a curfew from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff had scrambled to be ready.\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment -- including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\n'No communication'\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St Vincent and the Grenadines, said that it would take a \"herculean effort\" to rebuild after the substantial destruction and that \"90-odd percent of the houses were blown away\" on Union Island.\n\n\"Most of the country doesn't have electricity, and more than half without water at the moment,\" he said.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 13.5-square mile (35-square kilometre) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country's main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela's northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\nClimate change\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was damaged.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", {"uri": "8209825873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "15:51:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T15:51:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T15:51:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.stabroeknews.com/2024/07/04/news/world/hurricane-beryl-heads-for-cayman-islands-mexico-after-striking-jamaica/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl heads for Cayman Islands, Mexico after striking Jamaica - Stabroek News", "body": "KINGSTON, (Reuters) - Hurricane Beryl rumbled towards the Cayman Islands and Mexico today, after pummeling Jamaica with winds and rain that caused floods and widespread power outages and leaving a deadly trail of destruction in several smaller Caribbean islands.\n\nBeryl has so far left at least 10 people dead but that number was widely expected to rise as communications are restored on islands devastated by flooding and powerful winds.\n\nBeryl's eyewall skirted Jamaica's southern coast, pummeling communities as a powerful Category 4 storm on the five-step Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, as emergency workers evacuated people from flood-prone areas.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nBeryl moved away from Jamaica early on Thursday. At around 1200 GMT, the Category 3 hurricane was 50 miles (80 km) from Grand Cayman and about 385 miles (620 km) off Tulum, Mexico, the U.S. National Hurricane Center said.\n\nBeryl was carrying top winds of 130 mph (209 kph), and was expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands, where life-threatening surf and rip currents were possible, the NHC said.\n\nA hurricane warning was in force for the Cayman Islands east coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.\n\nMexico's tourist centres of Cancun and the wider Yucatan peninsula lie in Beryl's predicted path. Cancun's airport was thronged with tourists hoping to catch last flights out before the storm arrives. Workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection.\n\nMexico's defense ministry opened around 120 storm shelters, and asked visitors to heed instructions on evacuation or other measures.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and at its peak earlier this week was the earliest Category 5 storm on record. A Category 5 hurricane brings winds of 157 mph (252 kph) or higher, capable of causing catastrophic damage including the destruction of homes and infrastructure.\n\nJAMAICA AND SMALL ISLANDS\n\nIn Jamaica the island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a curfew for Wednesday, which was extended to Thursday as storm conditions continued. At least one person was reported killed in the storm.\n\nNearly 1,000 people were in shelters by Wednesday evening, Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency said in an interview on local news.\n\nThe storm hit St. Vincent and the Grenadines earlier in the week. Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves said in a radio interview that Union Island was \"flattened\" and it would \"be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nThere were at least three confirmed fatalities and crop damage was widespread, senior officials told Reuters. Union Island suffered destruction of more than 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions after the storm made impact earlier in the week, with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nVenezuelan President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died, four were missing, and over 8,000 homes damaged.\n\nThe U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year. The season runs from the start of June to the end of November\n\nBeryl's destructive power, coming so early in the hurricane season, underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather.", "source": {"uri": "stabroeknews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Stabroek News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-07-410576776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "23:07:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T23:07:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T23:06:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://globalnation.inquirer.net/241462/hurricane-beryl-hammers-jamaica-on-path-to-caymans-mexico", "title": "Hurricane Beryl hammers Jamaica on path to Caymans, Mexico", "body": "High waves crash along the beach in Kingston, Jamaica, before the arrival of Hurricane Beryl on July 3, 2024. Beryl churned towards Jamaica on July 3, with forecasters warning of potentially deadly winds and storm surge, after at least seven people were killed and widespread destruction was reported across the southeastern Caribbean. The powerful hurricane, which is rare so early in the Atlantic season, was expected to pass over Jamaica around midday as a \"life-threatening\" Category 4 storm, meteorologists said. (AFP)\n\nKINGSTON, Jamaica - Powerful Hurricane Beryl churned along Jamaica's southern coast on Wednesday, battering the island with dangerous winds and sea surge after leaving a trail of destruction and at least seven people dead in the Caribbean.\n\nThe eye of the Category 4 hurricane has not yet breached the shore of Jamaica but could in the coming hours, and is expected to approach or even make landfall in the Cayman islands overnight before moving onward to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nAhead of Beryl's arrival, people across Jamaica removed boats from the water and rushed to buy food, water, gasoline and other essentials.\n\nAs of Wednesday afternoon the storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 kph), said the NHC. Hurricane conditions are spreading through the island, it said.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness declared a curfew from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\n\"If you live in a low lying area, an area historically prone to flooding and landslide or if you live on the banks of a river, I implore you to evacuate to a shelter, or to safer ground,\" he said in a video posted to social media.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff has scrambled to be ready.\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment -- including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nMexican officials were meanwhile scrambling to prepare for Beryl, which is expected to hit somewhere between the well-known tourist hotspot of Tulum and the town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto, according to Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez.\n\nBeginning Thursday \"we will have intense rains and wind gusts\" she said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for some 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo where Beryl will hit.\n\n'No communication'\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 13.5-square mile (35-square kilometer) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country's main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela's northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\nClimate change\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was damaged.", "source": {"uri": "8209592519", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "13:08:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T13:08:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T13:07:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/International/hurricane-beryl-leaves-widespread-damage-jamaica-targets-mexico/story?id=111672009", "title": "Hurricane Beryl leaves widespread damage in Jamaica, targets Mexico and Texas", "body": "Hurricane Beryl has weakened to a Category 3 storm on Thursday, but not before leaving flooding and widespread damage on the island of Jamaica late Wednesday.\n\nBeryl's center passed just 45 miles south of Kingston, Jamaica, as a Category 4 hurricane with winds of 140 mph.\n\nBeryl was the first major hurricane -- at least a Category 3 -- to pass this close to Jamaica since 2007.\n\nBy Thursday morning, Beryl had weakened to Category 3 hurricane with winds of 120 mph, as it approaches the Cayman Islands.\n\nThe hurricane should pass just south of the Cayman Islands Thursday morning, bringing hurricane-force winds and storm surge that could produce a water rise of 4 to 6 feet as well as half a foot of rain.\n\nThe next landfall for Beryl will likely be on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, where major resorts such as Cancun, Playa De Carmen and Tulum are under hurricane warnings.\n\nBeryl could be a Category 1 hurricane as it reaches the Mexican resorts early Friday morning with wind gusts near 74 to 85 mph, storm surge up to 3 feet and up to 8 inches of rain.\n\nBy Friday evening, Beryl should cross into the southern Gulf of Mexico and weaken into a tropical storm.\n\nAs Beryl moves over the Gulf, in the direction of U.S.-Mexico border, it could re-intensify back into a hurricane, with winds near 75 mph ahead of landfall. Right now, it's too soon to tell exactly where it will make landfall along the Gulf Coast, with models predicting anywhere from northeastern Mexico to Texas' Gulf Coast.\n\nRegardless of Beryl's strength, it is expected to bring heavy rain to southern Texas.\n\nIn addition, the prolonged period of onshore winds along the U.S. Gulf Coast could create rough beach conditions, including a risk {"uri": "8208743431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "02:42:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T02:42:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T02:42:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/3005631-hurricane-beryls-wrath-a-caribbean-catastrophe", "title": "Hurricane Beryl's Wrath: A Caribbean Catastrophe | Science-Environment", "body": "Hurricane Beryl, a powerful Category 4 storm, devastated Jamaica and other Caribbean islands with heavy winds and rain, resulting in at least ten fatalities and widespread destruction. The storm's impact underscores the consequences of climate change and extreme weather. Recovery efforts are underway as affected regions brace for more challenges.\n\nHurricane Beryl thrashed Jamaica with heavy winds and rain on Wednesday, killing at least one person after forging a destructive, water-soaked path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple days. The death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane climbed to at least 10, but it is widely expected to rise further as communications come back online across drenched islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nIn Jamaica, Beryl's eyewall skirted the island's southern coast, pummeling communities as emergency groups rushed to evacuate people from flood-prone areas. \"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in Jamaica's southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nA woman died in Jamaica's Hanover parish after a tree fell on her home, Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency said in an interview on local news. Nearly a thousand Jamaicans were in shelters by Wednesday evening, Thompson added.\n\nThe island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a nationwide curfew for Wednesday. \"We can do as much as we can do, as (is) humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said earlier on Wednesday, urging residents in vulnerable areas to evacuate.\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a telltale sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather that differs from past experience. Ralph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one of the hardest-hit areas in the eastern Caribbean, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl.\n\n\"Everybody is homeless ... It is going to be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\" Speaking to state media, Nerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned of possible food shortages after 50% of the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nPower outages were widespread across Jamaica, while some roads near the coast were washed out. By Wednesday evening, the eye of the spiraling hurricane was located about 100 miles (161 km) west of Kingston, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC), as the storm's core headed toward the Cayman Islands, where hurricane conditions were expected late tonight.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 130 miles per hour (209 kph). The force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in the next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl would remain at or near major hurricane strength as it passed the Cayman Islands.\n\nBeryl is expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands overnight and into Thursday. Large swells were expected to \"cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions,\" the NHC said. The center added that a hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, as well as the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, including for the country's top beach resort Cancun.\n\n'ARMAGEDDON-LIKE' Additional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three din St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths. In Venezuela, President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8,000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nVenezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodriguez was injured by a falling tree on Tuesday as she surveyed an area south of Beryl where intense rainfall caused the Manzanares River in Sucre state to burst its banks, the president confirmed. The unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fueled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year. Beyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall as hurricane on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn the fishing village of Punta Allen, in the state of Quintana Roo, residents moved boats inland for safety, while navy officers implored reluctant residents to evacuate. In tourist epicenter Cancun, an environmental agency worked to gather eggs from sea turtles' nests for their protection. Tourists soaked up the sun's rays while they still could.\n\nMeanwhile, workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection. Officials said supplies of wooden boards were dwindling as Cancun locals and tourists prepared for Beryl's arrival. Laura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements once the hurricane approaches, in comments to local broadcaster Milenio.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-411263980", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "12:53:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T12:53:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T12:52:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://eu.news-press.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/07/04/hurricane-beryl-path-tracker-cayman-islands-florida-texas-impact-path/74293390007/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl eyewall passing Grand Cayman. What will be impact to Florida, Gulf Coast?", "body": "At least one person was killed by Hurricane Beryl in the Caribbean. It is expected to reach the eastern part of Mexico by the end of the week.\n\nThe weather was deteriorating in the Cayman Islands Saturday morning as Hurricane Beryl neared, expected to bring with it strong winds, dangerous storm surge and damaging waves, according to the National Hurricane Center's 8 a.m. advisory.\n\nThe storm's eyewall was passing southwest of Grand Cayman and the storm's westward to west-northwestward motion is expected to move the core of Beryl away from the Cayman Islands this morning and over the Yucatan Peninsula early Friday.\n\nBeryl lashed the southern coast of Jamaica Friday as a Category 4 hurricane with 140-mph winds.\n\nBeryl has weakened to a Category 3 hurricane packing 120 mph winds and is forecast to be near major hurricane intensity today as it passes by the Cayman Islands.\n\nThe storm is expected to remain a hurricane until it makes landfall on the Yucatan Peninsula, the NHC said.\n\nAfter emerging into the Gulf of Mexico, Beryl will likely have a couple of days to re-strengthen over warm waters with light or moderate shear.\n\nAlmost all of the model guidance show the system near hurricane strength as Beryl approaches the western Gulf Coast, and so does the official NHC forecast.\n\nBeryl's track and intensity over the western Gulf of Mexico this weekend remains uncertain. Interests in eastern Mexico and southern Texas should monitor the progress of Beryl, the NHC warns.\n\nRegardless of the exact track, rip currents could cause life-threatening beach conditions beginning late Friday and continuing through the weekend across much of the Gulf Coast.\n\nHurricane Beryl a storm without precedent. That's not good\n\nWhile Beryl poses a serious threat to the western Gulf of Mexico this weekend, its implications for the season ahead are also sobering, according to Dr. Ryan Truchelut, chief meteorologist at WeatherTiger. Truchelut works with the USA TODAY Network-Florida to provide the latest storm information Florida residents need.\n\nHurricane Beryl: Why a storm without precedent signals bad season ahead | WeatherTiger\n\n\"When Beryl peaked at Category 5 intensity on Tuesday, it became not only the earliest Category 5 in Atlantic history, but both the strongest June and strongest July hurricane on record.\"\n\nThis is especially remarkable given that any kind of early-season tropical development is rare in the eastern Atlantic, Truchelut said.\n\n\"In the last 150 years, there are 10 seasons in which a hurricane formed in the Main Development Region before August: 2021, 2020, 2018, 2008, 2005, 1996, 1961, 1933, 1926, and 1887. All of those years were above-normal hurricane seasons, averaging almost double the intensity of a normal season.\"\n\nWhat does that mean?\n\n\"You should do the things you can do now to prepare before the inevitable cone-panic hits. So, trim those trees, know where you would go if you need to evacuate, and make sure your hurricane kits are in good order, \" Truchelut said.\n\nAccuWeather forecasters: Impact to southern Texas depends on Beryl's strength\n\nAfter plowing into the Caribbean as a major hurricane, leaving death and destruction in its wake, Beryl is expected to make landfall on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, before heading into the Gulf of Mexico this weekend and making landfall again in northeastern Mexico, AccuWeather meteorologists predict.\n\n\u27a4 Track all active storms\n\nThe impact on northeastern Mexico and southern Texas will depend on how much Beryl strengthens over the Gulf and its speed when it arrives.\n\n\"A significant factor to consider is that Beryl's forward speed is likely to slow,\" AccuWeather Chief On-Air Meteorologist Bernie Rayno said.\n\nA slower-moving storm will increase the duration of wind, surf and storm surge.\n\nWhen it made its first landfall at 11 a.m. on Carriacou Island Monday, July 1, Beryl was a Category 4 storm with 150-mph winds.\n\nHistorically warm water affecting Beryl's strength\n\nFactors affecting Beryl's intensity include much warmer-than-historical-average waters and wind shear, according to AccuWeather forecasters. If wind shear is strong enough, it can lead to weakening of tropical systems. Warm water helps storms develop and intensify.\n\nAccuWeather Lead Tropical Meteorologist Alex DaSilva said water temperatures in early July are equal to what they usually are in late August, early September.\n\nSpaghetti models: Where will Hurricane Beryl go next?\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The Hurricane Center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nWatches and warnings issued for Hurricane Beryl\n\nFor an explanation of what the watches and warnings mean, scroll to the bottom of this story.\n\nHurricane warning: A hurricane warning is in effect for:\n\nHurricane watch: A hurricane watch is in effect for:\n\nTropical storm warning: A tropical storm warning is in effect for the following:\n\nTropical storm watch: A tropical storm watch is in effect for:\n\nHurricane Beryl\n\nHow strong is Hurricane Beryl and where is it going?\n\nKey messages from the National Hurricane Center: What you need to know about Hurricane Beryl\n\nCurrent forecast: How strong is Hurricane Beryl expected to get?\n\nWhat impact could Hurricane Beryl have and what areas could be affected?\n\nInteractive map: What tropical storms, hurricanes have impacted your area in the past?\n\nHurricane warning: A hurricane warning means that hurricane conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area. A warning is typically issued 36 hours before the anticipated first occurrence of tropical-storm-force winds, conditions that make outside preparations difficult or dangerous. Preparations to protect life and property should be rushed to completion.\n\nHurricane watch: A hurricane watch means that hurricane conditions are possible within the watch area. A watch is typically issued 48 hours before the anticipated first occurrence of tropical-storm-force winds, conditions that make outside preparations difficult or dangerous.\n\nTropical storm warning: A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nTropical storm watch: An announcement that sustained winds of 39 to 73 mph are possible within the specified area within 48 hours in association with a tropical, subtropical, or post-tropical cyclone.\n\nStorm surge warning: A storm surge warning means there is a danger of life-threatening inundation, from rising water moving inland from the coastline, in the indicated locations. This is a life-threatening situation. Persons located within these areas should take all necessary actions to protect life and property from rising water and the potential for other dangerous conditions. Follow evacuation and other instructions from local officials.\n\nStorm surge watch: A storm surge watch means there is a possibility of life-threatening inundation, from rising water moving inland from the coastline, in the indicated locations during the next 48 hours.", "source": {"uri": "news-press.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News-Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/hurricane-beryl-jamaica-caribbean-6426479-Jul2024/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl strikes Jamaica as death toll rises to nine", "body": "The Category 4 storm has left a trail of destruction in its path across the Caribbean.\n\nHURRICANE BERYL HAS battered Jamaica's southern coast with devastating winds and sea surge.\n\nThe Category 4 storm has left a trail of destruction in its path across the Caribbean, killing at least nine people as it has strengthened rapidly.\n\nBeryl was pulling away from Jamaica late last night and was expected to pass just south of the Cayman Islands overnight, before moving onward to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center (NHC) said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nMexican officials are scrambling to prepare, with Beryl expected to bring damaging winds, a dangerous storm surge and heavy rainfall over the Yucatan Peninsula and Belize.\n\n\"We will have intense rains and wind gusts\" from today, Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for around 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo, where Beryl will likely hit.\n\nIn Jamaica, \"life-threatening flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall\" were still expected overnight, the NHC said.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power, according to the Jamaica Gleaner newspaper, citing a public service company.\n\nThe devastating hurricane-force winds, life-threatening storm surge, and damaging waves that continue to damage Jamaica are expected in the Cayman Islands overnight, when Beryl passes by while at or near major hurricane intensity.\n\nJamaica Prime Minister Andrew Holness had declared a curfew from 6am to 6pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff had scrambled to be ready.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment -- including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nAs of last night, Beryl was packing maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph), said the NHC.\n\n'No communication'\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall on Monday.\n\nAccording to Reuters, three people were killed in St Vincent and the Grenadines, while in Venezuela, President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St Vincent and the Grenadines, said that it would take a \"herculean effort\" to rebuild after the substantial destruction and that \"90-odd percent of the houses were blown away\" on Union Island.\n\n\"Most of the country doesn't have electricity, and more than half without water at the moment,\" he said.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 35-square kilometer island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country's main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nClimate change\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between one and three degrees Celsius warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was damaged.\n\n\u00a9 AFP 2024", "source": {"uri": "thejournal.ie", {"uri": "8208860409", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "04:46:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T04:46:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T04:46:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/hurricane-beryl-approaches-jamaica-after-killing-7-people-in-southeast-caribbean/3265582", "title": "Hurricane Beryl approaches Jamaica after killing 7 people in southeast Caribbean", "body": "Beryl wreaks havoc on Caribbean islands and is now setting its sights on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula\n\nHeavy rains and strong winds from Hurricane Beryl pounded the coast of Jamaica on Wednesday after the powerful storm devastated parts of the southeast Caribbean, where it left a trail of death and destruction.\n\nAt least seven deaths have been attributed to the powerful storm: three in the Grenada islands, three in Venezuela and one in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.\n\nIt is the earliest Atlantic hurricane on record to reach Category 5 strength, meaning it has sustained winds stronger than 156 miles (251 kilometers) per hour, the highest marker on the Saffir-Simpson hurricane scale.\n\nVideos shared on social media showed destroyed homes and damaged police stations, schools, hospitals and streets.\n\nGrenada Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said that \"within half an hour\" Grenada's Carriacou island, which is home to around 9,000 people, \"was devastated.\"\n\n\"We have had virtually no communication with Carriacou for 12 hours,\" Mitchell said, confirming that there will probably be an increase in the number of deaths.\n\nAuthorities reported that 98% of the buildings on the island are damaged.\n\nBeryl now threatens Jamaica, where it is expected to make landfall in the next few hours as a dangerous Category 4 hurricane with sustained winds of 145 miles (233 kilometers) per hour. It will also reach the Cayman Islands and then enter the Yucatan Peninsula in Mexico on Thursday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).\n\n\"Beryl is expected to cause life-threatening winds and storm surge in Jamaica on Wednesday, and in the Cayman Islands on Wednesday night and Thursday,\" reported the NHC.\n\nThe World Meteorological Organization said that never before has a hurricane of such magnitude been recorded in the Atlantic at this time of year. Experts say its rapid intensification and devastating effects are consequences of the warming of the oceans caused by climate change.\n\nAccording to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, this year, the Atlantic will have a well above average hurricane season, with the possibility of up to 13 hurricanes.\n\nThe Caribbean community began Wednesday to coordinate shipments {"uri": "2024-07-410728682", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "04:10:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T04:10:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T04:08:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/americas/20240704-hurricane-beryl-jamaica-cayman-mexico", "title": "Hurricane Beryl strikes Jamaica, Cayman Islands and Mexico brace for impact", "body": "Category 4 Hurricane Beryl devastated the southern coast of Jamaica on Wednesday evening. The Cayman Islands and Mexico are bracing to be next.\n\nHurricane Beryl thrashed Jamaica with heavy winds and rain on Wednesday, killing at least one person after forging a destructive, water-soaked path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple days.\n\nThe death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane climbed to at least 10, but it is widely expected to rise further as communications come back online across drenched islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nIn Jamaica, Beryl's eyewall skirted the island's southern coast, pummeling communities as emergency groups rushed to evacuate people from flood-prone areas.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in Jamaica's southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nA woman died in Jamaica's Hanover parish after a tree fell on her home, Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency said in an interview on local news.\n\nNearly a thousand Jamaicans were in shelters by Wednesday evening, Thompson added.\n\nThe island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a nationwide curfew for Wednesday.\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as (is) humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said earlier on Wednesday, urging residents in vulnerable areas to evacuate.\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a telltale sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather that differs from past experience.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one of the hardest-hit areas in the eastern Caribbean, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl.\n\n\"Everybody is homeless ... It is going to be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nSpeaking to state media, Nerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned of possible food shortages after 50% of the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nPower outages were widespread across Jamaica, while some roads near the coast were washed out.\n\nBy Wednesday evening, the eye of the spiraling hurricane was located about 100 miles (161 km) west of Kingston, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC), as the storm's core headed toward the Cayman Islands, where hurricane conditions were expected late tonight.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 130 miles per hour (209 kph).\n\nThe force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in the next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl would remain at or near major hurricane strength as it passed the Cayman Islands.\n\nBeryl is expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands overnight and into Thursday. Large swells were expected to \"cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions,\" the NHC said.\n\nThe center added that a hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, as well as the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, including for the country's top beach resort Cancun.\n\n'ARMAGEDDON-LIKE'\n\nAdditional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three din St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nIn Venezuela, President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8,000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nVenezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodriguez was injured by a falling tree on Tuesday as she surveyed an area south of Beryl where intense rainfall caused the Manzanares River in Sucre state to burst its banks, the president confirmed.\n\nThe unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fueled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nBeyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall as hurricane on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn the fishing village of Punta Allen, in the state of Quintana Roo, residents moved boats inland for safety, while navy officers implored reluctant residents to evacuate.\n\nIn tourist epicenter Cancun, an environmental agency worked to gather eggs from sea turtles' nests for their protection. Tourists soaked up the sun's rays while they still could.\n\nMeanwhile, workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection. Officials said supplies of wooden boards were dwindling as Cancun locals and tourists prepared for Beryl's arrival.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements once the hurricane approaches, in comments to local broadcaster Milenio.", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Hurricane Beryl travel advice", "body": "Hurricane Beryl has reportedly destroyed 90 per cent of homes on Union Island as it roared through the south-east Caribbean, killing at least six people, with Jamaica next in its path.\n\nThe prime minister of St Vincent and the Grenadines, Ralph Gonsalves, said that most homes on Union Island were destroyed, and that \"similar levels of devastation\" were expected on the islands of Myreau and Canouan.\n\nSeveral people were evacuated from Union Island via ferry and arrived in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on Tuesday.\n\nSharon DeRoche, one of the evacuees, said Union Island is in a terrible state. She waited out the hurricane in her bathroom before she fled.\n\n\"It was a hard four hours battling with six of us in that little area,\" she said.\n\nA hurricane warning is in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac.\n\nBeryl is losing intensity but is forecast to still be near major-hurricane strength when it passes Jamaica and the Cayman Islands on Thursday and into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula on Friday, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nHurricane Beryl was roaring by Jamaica on Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain after the powerful category 4 storm earlier killed at least seven people and caused significant damage in the south-east Caribbean.\n\nThe US National Hurricane Center said Beryl's eyewall was \"brushing the south coast of Jamaica\".\n\nWind-whipped rain pounded the island for hours as residents heeded authorities' call to shelter until the storm had passed. Power was knocked out in much of the capital.\n\nThe prime minister, Andrew Holness, said on Wednesday afternoon that nearly 500 people were placed in shelters. By the evening, he said that Jamaica has not seen the \"worst of what could possibly happen\".\n\nHeavy rains of four to eight inches, with up to a foot in isolated areas, threatened flash flooding and mudslides on the mountainous island.\n\nAs Beryl barrelled through the Caribbean Sea, rescue crews in south-eastern islands fanned out to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nMichelle Forbes, the St Vincent and Grenadines director of the National Emergency Management Organisation, said that about 95 per cent of homes in Mayreau and Union Island have been damaged by Hurricane Beryl.\n\nThree people were reported killed in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said. One fatality in Grenada occurred after a tree fell on a house, Kerryne James, the environment minister, told the Associated Press.\n\nGrenada's prime minister, Dickon Mitchell, said on Tuesday there was no power, roads are impassable and the possible rise of the death toll \"remains a grim reality\".\n\nThree other deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, where five people are missing, officials said. About 25,000 people in that area also were affected by heavy rainfall from Beryl.\n\nBeryl is expected to bring life-threatening winds and storm surge to Jamaica, where officials warned residents in flood-prone areas to prepare for evacuation.\n\n\"I am encouraging all Jamaicans to take the hurricane as a serious threat,\" the country's prime minister said in a public address Tuesday. \"It is, however, not a time to panic.\"\n\nBut if you have a holiday booked to the area soon, where do you stand? Here is what we know.\n\nThe storm has proved highly destructive so far, with winds of up to 155 mph recorded on Grenada. Multiple airports in the region have been closed, so it's best to contact your travel provider if you have a trip booked to the Caribbean.\n\nThe Foreign Office said: \"A major hurricane moving through the Caribbean has impacted services in Barbados. Grantley Adams International Airport and Bridgetown Port reopened on 2 July 2024 with the resumption of commercial flights.\n\nYou should follow and monitor local and international weather updates from the US National Hurricane Center and follow the advice of local authorities, including any evacuation orders. See Extreme weather and natural disasters.\"\n\nAirports in Jamaica are currently closed.\n\nThe Foreign Office added: \" Disruption to services is expected island-wide. International and domestic airports are now closed and will only reopen when assessed safe to do so.\"\n\nCNN has a storm tracker map showing exactly where the hurricane has hit and where it is expected to travel to next here.\n\nEarly on Thursday the most recent data suggested the storm is rated at a category 3 and was in the centre of the Caribbean Sea.\n\nWinds are moving west, and are currently measured at 120mph.\n\nTropical force winds are expected to still hit Jamaica and the Cayman Islands. There is also a concern it is making its way towards Mexico.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8209319313", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:13:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:13:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:12:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.westhawaiitoday.com/2024/07/04/nation-world-news/hurricane-beryls-category-4-eye-sweeps-jamaicas-coast-roofs-ripped-from-airport-buildings/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl's Category 4 eye sweeps Jamaica's coast. Roofs ripped from airport, buildings - West Hawaii Today", "body": "The northern eyewall of Category 4 Hurricane Beryl scraped along Jamaica's southern coast Wednesday afternoon, walloping the island with high winds and drenching rains for most of the day with the worst impacts on the south end of the island.\n\nThe northern eyewall of Category 4 Hurricane Beryl scraped along Jamaica's southern coast Wednesday afternoon, walloping the island with high winds and drenching rains for most of the day with the worst impacts on the south end of the island.\n\nEarly Wednesday evening, reports of felled trees, impassable roads, extensive power outages and winds so strong they stripped roofs from buildings -- including the international airport -- began cropping up across Jamaica, where hundreds waited out the storm in hurricane shelters.\n\nIt's too soon to know the full extent of the havoc the storm wrought on the island nation, but it's already left at least seven dead from its first brush with the eastern Caribbean and leveled some of the smaller islands in the southeast Caribbean.\n\n\"It is almost Armageddon-like, almost total damage or destruction of all buildings whether they be public buildings, homes or other private facilities,\" said Grenada Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell after a helicopter survey on Tuesday.\n\nAs of the 5 p.m. Eastern time update Wednesday, the National Hurricane Center said Beryl was still holding on to its Category 4 status with 140 mph sustained winds, a slight decline from earlier in the day. In a potential good sign, the initial readings in the Jamaican capital Kingston were significantly less, with sustained winds topping 48 mph and a wind gust as high as 81 mph.\n\nAfter some slight weakening just before it closed in, Beryl appeared to be more organized Wednesday afternoon with a clear-out eye. Forecasters expect it to bring up to 9 feet of \"life-threatening\" storm surge and up to a foot of rain.\n\nBeryl was about 65 miles west-southwest of Kingston, Jamaica and headed west-northwest at 20 mph. Hurricane-force winds extended up to 45 miles from the storm's eye, putting Kingston within reach of the worst of the storm's winds and covering nearly the entire island with tropical-storm-force winds, which reached up to 185 miles from the center.\n\nJamaica was getting smacked with the upper right section of the storm, also known as the dirty side, which brings the most storm surge and holds the greatest potential for tornado formation. It's \"the worst side of the storm,\" wrote Sammy Hadi, a meteorologist with the Miami office of the National Weather Service, on Twitter.\n\nNext on the forecast track is the Cayman Islands, which are also under hurricane warnings. Beryl is on track to pass south of the islands on Thursday as a strong Category 3 before heading onward to the Yucatan Peninsula.\n\nFrom there, Beryl is forecast to make another landfall in the Quintana Roo region of Mexico as a Category 1 hurricane, before re-emerging in the Gulf of Mexico as a tropical storm. New on Wednesday morning, the hurricane center now predicts Beryl could re-strengthen to a Category 1 hurricane again before striking the northeast coast of Mexico.\n\nDamage toll rising\n\nJamaican news outlets began reporting widespread power and water outages Wednesday evening as floodwaters and fallen trees began to make some roads impassable. Part of the roof at Norman Manley International Airport in Kingston ripped off in the storm, video on social media shows.\n\nAs of 5 p.m., Jamaican Prime Minister Andrew Holness reported no official deaths and said that more than 500 people were relocated to hurricane shelters.\n\nJamaica also fully mobilized its security forces to maintain order, and extended the 6 p.m. cutoff time for the curfew as the storm continued to pound the island. As Jamaicans were getting swiped, Haiti announced it had lifted the alerts for its southern coast. The storm no longer presented a threat, a message from Haiti's Office of Civil Protection said.\n\nIn Grenada, which got slammed on Monday, officials reported an \"Armageddon-like\" impact. The hardest hit islands saw 98% of all homes and buildings destroyed, and massive damage to communications and the electrical grid.\n\n\"Complete devastation and destruction of agriculture. Complete and total destruction of the natural environment; there is literally no vegetation left anywhere on the island of Carriacou,\" Mitchell, the prime minister, said.\n\nIn Venezuela, nearly 1,500 people are homeless after Beryl's rains caused a river to overflow and destroy about 300 homes, El Caribe reported. Venezuela announced three more official deaths from the storm, bringing the latest total to seven dead.\n\nThe Caribbean Disaster Emergency Management agency, the regional body responsible for responding to disasters, said Wednesday there is not yet an official death toll and they are still assessing the destruction in member countries.\n\nElizabeth Riely, director of CDEMA, confirmed that while the Grenadines islands of Grenada and St. Vincent bore the brunt of the hurricane, Barbados, St. Lucia and Dominica were also affected.\n\nRiley said based on reports provided so far, they know that 100% of the population on the island of Canouan, which has 12,600 inhabitants, was affected by Beryl. \"There is an estimated 90% of the houses that were damaged either extensively or destroyed.\"\n\nElsewhere in the Atlantic, the hurricane center continued to drop the likelihood that another system would form behind Beryl. By Wednesday morning, it had a 20% chance of strengthening into a tropical depression this week.\n\nThe system dumped heavy rain on the already-ravaged islands Wednesday, prompting a flash flood
