{"uri": "2024-07-410558020", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "22:26:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T22:26:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T21:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.kadn.com/weather/hurricane/hurricane-beryl-brushes-southern-coast-of-jamaica-with-category-4-intensity/article_d2dd2878-3650-11ef-8b2f-83bfd295d24a.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl brushes southern coast of Jamaica with Category 4 intensity", "body": "ATLANTIC OCEAN (The Weather Channel) -- Hurricane Beryl has begun a potentially devastating strike on Jamaica and will then hammer the Cayman Islands and the Yucatan Peninsula before its final chapter in the Gulf of Mexico that will likely include impacts in eastern Mexico and Texas.\n\nBeryl is lashing Jamaica as its eyewall containing its strongest winds scrapes the southern part of the island. Winds gusted as high as 81 mph at Norman Manley International Airport on a peninsula south of the country's capital city, Kingston, Wednesday afternoon. On Beryl's eastern flank, bands of rain continue to wrap into parts of Haiti, which could result in flooding and mudslides.\n\nWednesday afternoon, the National Hurricane Center reported Beryl was located at 17.5\u00b0N 77.9\u00b0W and was moving west-northwest at 20 mph. Maximum sustained winds were 140 mph.\n\nBeryl Forecast Track - 7/3/24\n\nHurricane Beryl Forecast Track on July 3, 2024 (CREDIT: The Weather Channel)\n\nBeryl is the earliest hurricane to reach Category 5 strength on record in the Atlantic, and it beat the previous record by more than two weeks. The previous earliest Category 5 was Hurricane Emily on July 16 during the hyperactive 2005 Atlantic hurricane season. Record warm water temperature have likely catapulted Beryl's intensity.\n\nBeryl will take a west-northwest track in the Caribbean Sea through the rest of this week. Although the hurricane will eventually lose intensity because of increasingly hostile wind shear, it will still pose a considerable danger. Here's the general timeline:\n\nThrough Wednesday Night: Beryl will continue to lash Jamaica with potentially devastating winds, especially over mountainous terrain, and life-threatening storm surge flooding that could reach 6 to 9 feet above normal tide levels where winds blow onshore on the coast into the evening. Torrential rainfall could last through the overnight hours, triggering flash flooding and landslides in Jamaica. This is the strongest hurricane to strike Jamaica in almost 17 years, since Hurricane Dean in 2007.Wednesday Night and Early Thursday: Beryl will make its closest approach to the Cayman Islands, particularly Grand Cayman, with storm surge flooding, high winds, and heavy rain.Thursday Night and Friday: While conditions will deteriorate Thursday night, Beryl is expected to make a landfall as a hurricane in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, anywhere from the Belize border and Costa Maya to Cozumel. Storm surge flooding, potentially damaging winds and flooding rain are all possible. Heavy rain and strong wind gusts will continue in the Yucatan Peninsula through Friday.\n\nBeryl is likely to emerge in the southwest Gulf of Mexico this weekend after being steered by a heat dome of high pressure over the Southeast U.S. There is considerable uncertainty in Beryl's future after that.\n\nThat Southeast U.S. upper-level heat dome is expected to both weaken and retreat off the Southeast coast, leaving a gap between that and a western U.S. heat dome.\n\nBecause of that, some computer forecast models are suggesting Beryl could eventually curl more toward the northwest or north in the western Gulf of Mexico. That opens the door to a track anywhere from eastern Mexico's Gulf Coast to Texas early next week.\n\nBeryl should have lost strength by the time it reaches the southwest Gulf because of wind shear and land interaction, however it could still bring significant impacts to the Gulf Coast as either a tropical storm or hurricane. Some restrengthening is possible.\n\nCLICK HERE for more.", "source": {"uri": "kadn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KADN News 15"}, "authors": [{"uri": "weather_channel@kadn.com", "name": "Weather {"uri": "2024-07-410840109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "06:36:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T06:36:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T05:37:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/hurricane-beryl-churns-towards-mexico-after-hammering-jamaica/article_c8926620-3c42-52af-b209-e1372d6222cc.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl churns towards Mexico after hammering Jamaica", "body": "Deadly Hurricane Beryl powered towards Mexico late Wednesday, after battering Jamaica's southern coast with devastating winds and sea surge.\n\nThe Category 4 storm has left a trail of destruction in its path across the Caribbean, killing at least seven people as it has strengthened rapidly.\n\nBeryl was pulling away from Jamaica late Wednesday and was expected to pass just south of the Cayman Islands overnight, before moving onward to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center (NHC) said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nMexican officials are scrambling to prepare, with Beryl expected to bring damaging winds, a dangerous storm surge and heavy rainfall over the Yucatan Peninsula and Belize.\n\n\"We will have intense rains and wind gusts\" from Thursday, Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for around 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo, where Beryl will likely hit.\n\nIn Jamaica, \"life-threatening flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall\" were still expected overnight, the NHC said.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power, according to the Jamaica Gleaner newspaper, citing a public service company.\n\nThe devastating hurricane-force winds, life-threatening storm surge, and damaging waves that continue to damage Jamaica are expected in the Cayman Islands overnight, when Beryl passes by while at or near major hurricane intensity.\n\nJamaica Prime Minister Andrew Holness had declared a curfew from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff had scrambled to be ready.\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment -- including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nAs of Wednesday night, Beryl was packing maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph), said the NHC.\n\n- 'No communication' -\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St Vincent and the Grenadines, said that it would take a \"herculean effort\" to rebuild after the substantial destruction and that \"90-odd percent of the houses were blown away\" on Union Island.\n\n\"Most of the country doesn't have electricity, and more than half without water at the moment,\" he said.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 13.5-square mile (35-square kilometer) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country's main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela's northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\n- Climate change -\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was damaged.\n\nbur-dw-bfm/dhw\n\nMore from this section\n\nCenterpoint Appoints Galen Baggs as New Chief Operating Officer\n\nSuper Incubator: Hatching Pok\u00e9mon Eggs without Walking or Moving at the Pokemon GO Fest 2024\n\nBest Way to Hatch Eggs without Moving or Walking at Pokemon GO Fest 2024", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8208698843", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "01:48:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T01:48:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T01:46:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/587208", "title": "Hurricane Beryl strikes Jamaica as death toll creeps up, destruction widespread", "body": "KINGSTON - Hurricane Beryl churned menacingly over Jamaica on Wednesday afternoon, after uprooting trees, ripping off roofs and destroying farms as it forged a destructive, water-soaked path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple days.\n\nThe death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane rose to at least nine, but it is widely expected to rise as communications come back online across drenched islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nIn Jamaica, the storm hit the island's southern coast on Wednesday afternoon, pummeling communities with intense wind and rain as emergency groups evacuated people living in flood-prone communities.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in Jamaica's southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nAlmost 500 Jamaicans were in shelters by Wednesday afternoon, Prime Minister Andrew Holness told reporters, urging people in high-risk areas to move.\n\nALSO READ: La Nina threatens Latin America with hurricanes and droughts, experts say\n\n\"We have not seen the worst of what could happen,\" Holness said. \"We can do as much as we can do, as (is) humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God.\"\n\nThe airports in the Jamaican capital, Kingston, and tourist-popular Montego Bay were closed throughout the day.\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a telltale sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather that differs from past experience.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one of the hardest-hit areas in the eastern Caribbean, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl.\n\n\"Everybody is homeless ... It is going to be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nSpeaking to state media, Nerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned of possible food shortages after 50 percent of the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nIn Kingston, streets were quiet as anxious residents hunkered down after spending the morning stocking up on essential supplies.\n\nJamaicans braced for electricity cuts later on Wednesday, according to a power company official, with roads near the coast already washed out as steady rain continued to fall and winds picked up in the capital.\n\nIn St. Elizabeth, local politician Joseph Patterson said the power was out and the situation was \"getting gradually worse by the minute,\" with aggressive winds bringing down trees.\n\nBy Wednesday afternoon, the well-defined eye of the spiraling hurricane was located about 105 km southeast of Kingston, according to the US National Hurricane Center (NHC), though its outer rings were already lashing much of the island with a population of nearly 3 million.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 225 kph.\n\nALSO READ: Hurricane Beryl, churning toward Jamaica, threatens Haiti & Dominican Republic\n\nThe force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl will remain at or near major hurricane strength as it moves on to the Cayman Islands.\n\n\"Life-threatening flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall are expected over much of Jamaica and southern Haiti through today,\" the NHC said in a post, adding that dangerous winds and storm surge are also expected in the Cayman Islands through early Thursday.\n\nThe center added that a hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, as well as the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, including for the country's top beach resort Cancun.\n\n'We could not sleep'\n\nOvernight in Haiti as Beryl's impact grew progressively stronger, residents anxiously awaited its full impact.\n\n\"We were not comfortable. We could not sleep normally with the wind, the water. Many people slept in the yard,\" said Pouchon Jean-Francois, who lives in an improvised camp in Port-au-Prince.\n\nVenezuelan Vice-President Delcy Rodriguez was injured as she surveyed an area south of Beryl on Tuesday night, where the Manzanares River in Sucre state burst its banks.\n\nPresident Nicolas Maduro confirmed the injuries caused by a falling tree to his second-in-command, along with head injuries suffered by senior officials accompanying her, after intense rainfall struck inland from the country's Caribbean coastline.\n\nOn Tuesday night, Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8,000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nThe unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fueled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nAdditional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90 percent of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nBeyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn Cancun, officials said supplies of wooden boards used to protect doors and windows were dwindling as locals and tourists prepared for Beryl's arrival.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements once the hurricane approaches, in comments to local broadcaster Milenio.", "source": {"uri": "chinadailyasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "China Daily Asia"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-411535748", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "17:24:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T17:24:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T17:01:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/hurricane-beryl-leaves-widespread-damage-125821779.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl leaves widespread damage in Jamaica, targets Mexico and Texas", "body": "Hurricane Beryl has weakened to a Category 3 storm on Thursday, but not before leaving flooding and widespread damage on the island of Jamaica late Wednesday.\n\nBeryl's center passed just 45 miles south of Kingston, Jamaica, as a Category 4 hurricane with winds of 140 mph.\n\nBeryl was the first major hurricane -- at least a Category 3 -- to pass this close to Jamaica since 2007.\n\nBy Thursday morning, Beryl had weakened to a Category 3 hurricane with winds of 115 mph.\n\nThe hurricane passed just south of the Cayman Islands Thursday morning, bringing hurricane-force winds and storm surge that could produce a water rise of 4 to 6 feet as well as half a foot of rain.\n\nThe next landfall for Beryl will likely be on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, where major resort areas such as Cancun, Playa Del Carmen and Tulum are under hurricane warnings.\n\nBeryl could be a Category 1 hurricane as it reaches the Mexican resorts with 80 mph winds, storm surge up to 3 feet and up to 8 inches of rain. It is expected to make landfall just south of Tulum on Friday morning around 5 a.m. ET.\n\nMORE: Record warm ocean temperatures allowed Hurricane Beryl to become the earliest Category 5 Atlantic storm\n\nBy Friday evening, Beryl should cross into the southern Gulf of Mexico and weaken into a tropical storm.\n\nAs Beryl moves over the Gulf, in the direction of the U.S.-Mexico border, it could re-intensify back into a hurricane, with winds near 75 mph ahead of landfall sometime Monday morning. Right now, it's too soon to tell exactly where it will make landfall along the Gulf Coast, with models predicting just south of the U.S.-Mexico border.\n\nRegardless of Beryl's strength, it is expected to bring heavy rain to southern Texas and could produce coastal flooding on the Texas Gulf Coast, from Galveston to South Padre Island, and the Florida Panhandle.\n\nIn addition, the prolonged period of onshore winds along the U.S. Gulf Coast could create rough beach conditions, including a risk for rip currents this holiday weekend.\n\nJamaica assessing damage\n\nDamage has been reported in southern Jamaica after Beryl battered the island.\n\nAt the height of the storm, hundreds of thousands -- about 65% -- of customers were without power. Jamaica Public Service said teams are making remote assessments and waiting on an all-clear from emergency management to make ground assessments and begin the restoration process.\n\nOne of the main cell providers in Jamaica -- Digicel -- has been down since the overnight hours and is working on network restoration.\n\nThe island's three major airports closed on Tuesday as the storm approached, stranding travelers. Sangster International Airport in Montego Bay said it will reopen at 6 p.m. local time Thursday. Guards at the airport told ABC News the facility sustained some damage.\n\nNorman Manley International Airport in Kingston said it plans to reopen Friday at 5 a.m. local time. It saw some minor damage from the storm, including a small section of the roof of the passenger boarding pier that blew off.\n\nIt is unclear when Ian Fleming International Airport in Ocho Rios will reopen.\n\nABC News' Faith Abubey contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "max_golembo@yahoo.com", "name": "Max Forecasts showed the the storm's northern eye wall, with its most destructive winds, brushing over the shoreline.\n\nThough the storm had weakened overnight from record-breaking Category 5 storm, forecasters said Wednesday its core was making a bit of a comeback and the storm's eye was once again becoming better defined.\n\n\"While westerly shear continues to affect Beryl, the central core of the hurricane has made a bit of a comeback this afternoon with the eye becoming better defined in Cuban radar data and re-appearing in satellite imagery,\" said Senior Hurricane Specialist Jack Beven in a 4 p.m. discussion message.\n\nHurricane forecasters say Beryl is expected to make landfall as a hurricane over the Yucatan Peninsula in the next few days. It's then expected to weaken into a tropical storm but restrengthen over the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nForecasters still warn that forecasts concerning Beryl's track and intensity over the western Gulf are uncertain, but current models show the storm making landfall again in northern Mexico or southern Texas on Sunday afternoon.\n\nA mid-level ridge of high pressure over the southeastern United States, which is causing extreme heat warnings across much of the Gulf Coast, is expected to continue steering Beryl west-northwest.\n\nBeryl heads towards Yucatan Peninsula\n\nOver the next few hours, Beryl is expected to continue bringing damaging winds and life-threatening storm surge to Jamaica and the Cayman Islands and cause significant mudslides in Jamaica and Haiti through Wednesday.\n\nAs it moves west, the storm should experience westerly wind shear, likely weakening it.\n\nIn the next 24-48 hours, Beryl is expected to reach the Yucatan Peninsula and make landfall as a hurricane.\n\nHurricane conditions are expected to reach areas of the Yucatan and Belize by Thursday night, and hurricane and tropical storm warnings have been issued for those areas.\n\nAfter landfall, the storm is expected to weaken into a tropical storm before emerging over the Gulf on Saturday.\n\nBeryl's track in the Gulf\n\nThe warm waters of the Gulf are expected to strengthen the system back into a hurricane as it moves west or northwest.\n\nFor now, the National Hurricane Center's cone shows the storm making landfall somewhere on the northern Mexico or southern Texas coast on Reuters\n\nHurricane Beryl barrelled toward Jamaica as a powerful Category 4 storm on Wednesday, after flattening homes and devastating agriculture on smaller islands in the eastern Caribbean, killing at least three people.\n\nAt around 0500 EDT (0900 GMT), the hurricane was about 300 km east-southeast of the Jamaican capital of Kingston, according the US National Hurricane Center (NHC), packing maximum sustained winds of 230 kmph.\n\n\"Beryl is expected to bring life-threatening winds and storm surge to Jamaica on Wednesday and the Cayman Islands on Wednesday night and Thursday,\" NHC said in an advisory. A hurricane warning is in effect for both places.\n\nHurricane conditions are expected to reach the coast of Jamaica about midday local time, with tropical storm-strength winds from late morning, making outside preparations difficult or dangerous, it said.\n\nIn the capital Kingston, cars queued at petrol stations as people filled additional containers with fuel. Residents stocked up on water and other essential supplies and boarded up shops and houses.\n\n\"Yeah right now (we're) worrying about the storm. You know it's Category 5 and in Jamaica people are worried and always shopping and buying things as in this store,\" Andre, a salesperson in a local store said, without giving his full name. The unusually early hurricane, whose rapid strengthening scientists said was likely fuelled by human-caused climate change, is expected to still be a hurricane when it passes near Jamaica and the Cayman Islands later this week.\n\nBeryl, the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson Scale, felled power lines and unleashed flash floods across smaller islands.\n\nThe storm hit St. Vincent and the Grenadines especially hard, according to Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves.\n\n\"The hurricane has come and gone, and it has left in its wake immense destruction,\" he said. On one island in the Grenadines archipelago, Union Island, 90 per cent of homes had been \"severely damaged or destroyed\", he said. The Prime Minister confirmed one death.\n\nIn a briefing on Tuesday, Grenada's Prime Minister, Dickon Mitchell, said Carriacou and Petite Martinique, two of the three islands that make up the country, {"uri": "2024-07-411381390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "14:40:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T14:40:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T14:37:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://eu.palmbeachpost.com/story/weather/hurricane/2024/07/04/jamaica-damage-hurricane-beryl-aftermath-photos/74295862007/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl soaks Jamaica: See photos of the damage after Category 4 hurricane", "body": "Jamaica was battered by Beryl throughout the day Wednesday. The outer bands lashed the Caribbean island nation Wednesday morning before the eyewall brushed the south coast of Jamaica in the mid-afternoon. Beryl was a Category 4 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 140 mph at the time.\n\nThe storm was projected to pound Jamaica with 4 to 8 inches of rain with localized amounts of 12 inches. Storm trackers captured waves up to 25 feet as Beryl made its way to Jamaica, which has a population of 3 million people. The center was 45 miles from the capital city of Kingston by mid-afternoon. One woman died after a tree fell on her home, said Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency. He also said nearly 1,000 residents were in shelters by Wednesday evening.\n\nBeryl made history by becoming the earliest category 4 and 5 hurricane on record and developed from a tropical storm into a major hurricane (winds of 111 mph or higher) in just over 12 hours. It first made landfall Monday on Grenada's Carriacou Island with wind speeds touching 150 mph.\n\nForecasters say Beryl is projected to approach the Cayman Islands before moving toward the Yucatan Peninsula on Thursday. It is expected to hit the mainland of Mexico late Sunday, and some models have it making landfall again in Texas.\n\nSee images from Jamaica after Hurricane Beryl\n\nHurricane Beryl tracker: Where is the storm going next?\n\nHurricane Beryl spaghetti models: Is Cancun, Mexico in storm's path?\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The Hurricane Center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.", "source": {"uri": "eu.palmbeachpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8209349820", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:32:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:32:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:31:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.gmanetwork.com/news/topstories/world/912281/hurricane-beryl-steams-towards-cayman-islands-mexico-after-striking-jamaica/story/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl steams towards Cayman Islands, Mexico after striking Jamaica", "body": "KINGSTON -- Hurricane Beryl steamed towards the Cayman Islands and Mexico on Thursday, after thrashing Jamaica with intense wind and rain, causing floods and power outages after forging a destructive path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple of days.\n\nThe death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane climbed to at least 10 across the region, and is widely expected to rise further as communications return on islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nAs Beryl moved away from Jamaica early on Thursday, the island discontinued its hurricane warning but kept a flash flood watch, the Meteorological Service of Jamaica said on X.\n\nBy late Wednesday, the storm's eye was about 100 miles (161 km) west of Kingston, according to the US National Hurricane Center (NHC), as its core headed toward the Cayman Islands.\n\nPacking maximum sustained winds of 130 miles per hour (209 kph), Beryl was expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands into Thursday, where a hurricane warning was in effect and life-threatening surf and rip currents were possible, NHC said.\n\nA hurricane warning was also in force for the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.\n\nAround 0900 GMT, the Category 3 hurricane was just 55 miles from Grand Cayman and about 440 miles off Tulum Mexico, NHC said.\n\nJamaica\n\nBeryl's eyewall skirted Jamaica's southern coast, pummeling communities as emergency groups evacuated people from flood-prone areas.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nA woman died in Jamaica's Hanover parish after a tree fell on her home, Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency said in an interview on local news.\n\nNearly a thousand Jamaicans were in shelters by Wednesday evening, Thompson added.\n\nThe island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a curfew for Wednesday, which was extended Thursday as storm conditions continued.\n\nWarming ocean\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl and that it would \"be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nNerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned on state media of possible food shortages after half the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nPower outages were widespread across Jamaica, while some roads near the coast were washed out.\n\n'Armageddon-like'\n\nConfirmed fatalities included at least three in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island suffered destruction of more than 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nIn Venezuela, President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing, with over 8,000 homes damaged.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record. The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nIn tourist epicenter Cancun, workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection and officials said supplies of wooden boards were dwindling.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, {"uri": "8208752630", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "02:54:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T02:54:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T02:54:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/hurricane-beryl-strikes-jamaica-as-caymans-mexico-brace-for-storms-impact/articleshow/111473540.cms", "title": "Hurricane Beryl strikes Jamaica as Caymans, Mexico brace for storm's impact", "body": "Hurricane Beryl thrashed Jamaica with heavy winds and rain on Wednesday, killing at least one person after forging a destructive, water-soaked path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple days.\n\nThe death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane climbed to at least 10, but it is widely expected to rise further as communications come back online across drenched islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nIn Jamaica, Beryl's eyewall skirted the island's southern coast, pummeling communities as emergency groups rushed to evacuate people from flood-prone areas.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in Jamaica's southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nA woman died in Jamaica's Hanover parish after a tree fell on her home, Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency said in an interview on local news.\n\nNearly a thousand Jamaicans were in shelters by Wednesday evening, Thompson added.\n\nThe island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a nationwide curfew for Wednesday.\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as (is) humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said earlier on Wednesday, urging residents in vulnerable areas to evacuate.\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a telltale sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather that differs from past experience.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one of the hardest-hit areas in the eastern Caribbean, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl.\n\n\"Everybody is homeless ... It is going to be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nSpeaking to state media, Nerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned of possible food shortages after 50% of the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nPower outages were widespread across Jamaica, while some roads near the coast were washed out.\n\nBy Wednesday evening, the eye of the spiraling hurricane was located about 100 miles (161 km) west of Kingston, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC), as the storm's core headed toward the Cayman Islands, where hurricane conditions were expected late tonight.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 130 miles per hour (209 kph).\n\nThe force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in the next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl would remain at or near major hurricane strength as it passed the Cayman Islands.\n\nBeryl is expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands overnight and into Thursday. Large swells were expected to \"cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions,\" the NHC said.\n\nThe center added that a hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, as well as the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, including for the country's top beach resort Cancun.\n\n'ARMAGEDDON-LIKE'\n\nAdditional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three din St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nIn Venezuela, President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8,000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nVenezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodriguez was injured by a falling tree on Tuesday as she surveyed an area south of Beryl where intense rainfall caused the Manzanares River in Sucre state to burst its banks, the president confirmed.\n\nThe unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fueled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nBeyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall as hurricane on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn the fishing village of Punta Allen, in the state of Quintana Roo, residents moved boats inland for safety, while navy officers implored reluctant residents to evacuate.\n\nIn tourist epicenter Cancun, an environmental agency worked to gather eggs from sea turtles' nests for their protection. Tourists soaked up the sun's rays while they still could.\n\nMeanwhile, workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection. Officials said supplies of wooden boards were dwindling as Cancun locals and tourists prepared for Beryl's arrival.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements once the hurricane approaches, in comments to local broadcaster Milenio.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "https://img.etimg.com/thumb/msid-111473544,width-1200,height-630,imgsize-108446,overlay-economictimes/photo.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9704864", "eventUri": "eng-9704864", {"uri": "8208703464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "01:55:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T01:55:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T01:53:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/world/2024/07/hurricane-beryl-hits-jamaica-creating-widespread-destruction.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl hits Jamaica, creating widespread destruction | Newshub", "body": "Hurricane Beryl churned menacingly over Jamaica on Wednesday afternoon, after uprooting trees, ripping off roofs and destroying farms as it forged a destructive, water-soaked path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple days.\n\nThe death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane rose to at least nine, but it is widely expected to rise as communications come back online across drenched islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nIn Jamaica, the storm hit the island's southern coast on Wednesday afternoon, pummeling communities with intense wind and rain as emergency groups evacuated people living in flood-prone communities.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in Jamaica's southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nAlmost 500 Jamaicans were in shelters by Wednesday afternoon, Prime Minister Andrew Holness told reporters, urging people in high-risk areas to move.\n\n\"We have not seen the worst of what could happen,\" Holness said. \"We can do as much as we can do, as (is) humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God.\"\n\nThe airports in the Jamaican capital, Kingston, and tourist-popular Montego Bay were closed throughout the day.\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a telltale sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather that differs from past experience.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one of the hardest-hit areas in the eastern Caribbean, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl.\n\n\"Everybody is homeless ... It is going to be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nSpeaking to state media, Nerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned of possible food shortages after 50% of the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nIn Kingston, streets were quiet as anxious residents hunkered down after spending the morning stocking up on essential supplies.\n\nJamaicans braced for electricity cuts later on Wednesday, according to a power company official, with roads near the coast already washed out as steady rain continued to fall and winds picked up in the capital.\n\nIn St. Elizabeth, local politician Joseph Patterson said the power was out and the situation was \"getting gradually worse by the minute,\" with aggressive winds bringing down trees.\n\nBy Wednesday afternoon, the well-defined eye of the spiraling hurricane was located about 65 miles (105 km) southeast of Kingston, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC), though its outer rings were already lashing much of the island with a population of nearly 3 million.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 140 miles per hour (225 kph).\n\nThe force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl will remain at or near major hurricane strength as it moves on to the Cayman Islands.\n\n\"Life-threatening flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall are expected over much of Jamaica and southern Haiti through today,\" the NHC said in a post, adding that dangerous winds and storm surge are also expected in the Cayman Islands through early Thursday.\n\nThe center added that a hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, as well as the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, including for the country's top beach resort Cancun.\n\n'We could not sleep'\n\nOvernight in Haiti as Beryl's impact grew progressively stronger, residents anxiously awaited its full impact.\n\n\"We were not comfortable. We could not sleep normally with the wind, the water. Many people slept in the yard,\" said Pouchon Jean-Francois, who lives in an improvised camp in Port-au-Prince.\n\nVenezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodriguez was injured as she surveyed an area south of Beryl on Tuesday night, where the Manzanares River in Sucre state burst its banks.\n\nPresident Nicolas Maduro confirmed the injuries caused by a falling tree to his second-in-command, along with head injuries suffered by senior officials accompanying her, after intense rainfall struck inland from the country's Caribbean coastline.\n\nOn Tuesday night, Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8,000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nThe unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fueled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nAdditional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nBeyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn Cancun, officials said supplies of wooden boards used to protect doors and windows were dwindling as locals and tourists prepared for Beryl's arrival.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements once the hurricane approaches, in comments to local broadcaster Milenio.\n\nReuters", "source": {"uri": "newshub.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newshub"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-410698738", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "03:23:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T03:23:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T02:20:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/a-dangerous-hurricane-beryl-may-hit-texas-as-a-category-5-superstorm-soon-following-its-impact-on-jamaica-with-powerful-winds-and-high-waves/", "title": "A dangerous hurricane, Beryl, may hit Texas as a Category 5 superstorm soon, following its impact on Jamaica with powerful winds and high waves. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Hurricane Beryl struck the island nation of Jamaica Wednesday, bringing with it fierce winds and heavy rains - and Texas could be next.\n\nThe Category 4 storm's eyewall was sent brushing by the island country's south coast in the afternoon, creating hurricane conditions for more than 2.8million residents.\n\nThe storm has already made history as the strongest hurricane ever recorded in July, before it was downgraded from a Category 5 Tuesday. The historic hurricane, however, has only weakened slightly, packing a 140 mph punch and already being blamed for seven deaths in other countries.\n\nJamaican officials, as a result, pleaded with residents to take the storm seriously -urging evacuations as storm surges make flooding possible. As of writing, no deaths have been reported there, the storm's path remains somewhat uncertain.\n\nThe Americas, however, appears to be the storm's next stop, weather officials said - with either Mexico or Texas set to be hit next within the next 48 hours, by an even stronger version of the storm that's already killed at least seven.\n\n'Hurricane Beryl has so far brought a lot of water,' Jamaica Prime Minister Andrew Holness wrote in a post to X just after 6pm ET.\n\n'Please stay as safe as you can and remember to use the emergency contacts if you need them.'\n\nHours earlier, the National Hurricane Center issued its own update, as nine-foot waves were seen barreling into Jamaica's southern seaboard.\n\nIt advertised a still-ongoing Hurricane Warning, 'in effect for Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman and Cayman Brac, and the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun.'\n\nA less severe Hurricane Watch, meanwhile, was issued for the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico south of Puerto Costa Maya to Chetumal, and the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico north of Cancun to Cabo Catoche.\n\nA Hurricane Warning refers to when hurricane conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area, while a Hurricane Watch means that hurricane conditions are possible within an area, generally within 48 hours.\n\nFor the former, 'preparations to protect life and property should be rushed to completion,' the hurricane center said.\n\nNational Hurricane Center Director Michael Brennan added how storm surges of 6 to 9 feet above normal are expected, as the counterclockwise-rotating storm pushes water onto Jamaica's coast Wednesday night.\n\nThe storm is currently moving west, where it may strike the southern part of Mexico before potentially engaging in a rare double strike of the country by passing over its eponymous gulf and toward more northern cities like Monterrey.\n\nThat said, Beryl's path remains unpredictable, and state authorities in Texas are warning people - particularly in coastal areas - about the prospect of a July 4 hurricane or tropical storm.\n\n'While Texans take time to enjoy the holiday weekend with family and friends, it's important to stay weather aware, pay close attention to the rapidly-changing forecasts,' Texas Emergency Management Chief Nim Kidd said in a statement.\n\n'[D]on't be caught without an emergency plan.'\n\n'If I lived in Texas, and I have lived in Texas, this would be a storm that I would be watching closely,' FOX Weather Meteorologist Britta Merwin added.\n\n'The possible impacts would be Sunday into Monday.'\n\nAs of writing, the southern state seems more set be spared, with Mexico the more likely candidate.\n\nBut Texas Gov. Greg Abbott on Wednesday still told the state's Division of Emergency Management to issue a hurricane advisory notice to the Texas Emergency Management Council.\n\n'Texas stands ready to deploy all available resources and support to our coastal communities,' the Republican said, urging Texans to be ready for the still-real prospect the tropical weather will reach the US's Gulf Coast.\n\nIn Jamaica, though, extensive damage already appears unavoidable, with the storm then projected to cross the Yucatan Peninsula sometime Friday.\n\nBy then, it will against strengthen into a Category 5, officials said - after it had already achieved that status Monday.\n\nThere, it will move into the Gulf of Mexico, before slamming into either Mexico or southern Texas, weather officials said.\n\nAs of 5pm Wednesday, the hurricane's center had already passed through the capital Kingston, still some 265 miles from Grand Cayman, as the storm moved past the country.\n\nIt is currently moving west-northwest at speeds of around 20mph, while the winds whipping around insight of it are around seven times faster.\n\n'The Cayman Islands are sort of next in line for seeing significant impacts,' Brennan on Wednesday added, after some slight weakening occurred as the storm approached Jamaica earlier in the day.\n\nAuthorities at the time made it clear how the storm was a major weather event that should be taken seriously, with Prime Minister Holness telling those in low-lying areas and areas historically prone to flooding and landslide to evacuate.\n\nHe further urged those living on the banks of a river to either 'evacuate to a shelter or to safer ground,' hours before the storm made landfall.\n\nPeople proceeded to board up windows, and fishermen pulled their boats out of the surrounding water.\n\nWorkers, meanwhile, worked to dismantle roadside advertising boards to protect them from the lashing winds, just before wind-whipped rains plowed into the island for several hours.\n\nPower was knocked out in much of the capital, but by the evening, the storm had glanced off the island and continued making its way toward the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nIn an ensuing social media post, Prime Minister Holness revealed that nearly 500 Jamaicans had been placed in shelters.\n\n'We are placing emphasis on ensuring they are comfortable and well looked after,' he said.\n\nEarlier in the day, as churning whitecaps brought by Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast, Jon Porter, chief meteorologist at AccuWeather, issued a statement citing the dangerous nature of the storm\n\n'We are very concerned about a wide variety of life threatening impacts in Jamaica,\" he said, before branding Beryl 'the strongest and most dangerous hurricane threat that Jamaica has faced, probably, in decades.'\n\nAs a result Jamaica was under a state of emergency, and afterward was declared a disaster zone hours before the impact.\n\nHolness says the disaster zone declaration will remain for the next seven days, as he implemented an island-wide curfew.\n\nThe hours for the restrictions were between 6 am and 6 pm, and were in effect only Wednesday.\n\nThe curfew has since passed, with officials now surveying the damage.\n\nOn Monday, Beryl strengthened to a Category 5 hurricane for the first time, and by early Tuesday it was creating record-breaking 165 mph maximum sustained winds.\n\nThe small island nation of St. Vincent and the Grenadines were among those hit, with at least one person dead and more casualties likely as officials continue to probe flooded areas and wreckage.\n\nIn Grenada, at least three people have died, after Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said a unspecified number of homes had been destroyed by the \"Armageddon-like\" storm.\n\nVenezuela was also hit by heavy flooding that caused the deaths of at least, as four more remain missing as a result of the storm, the country's president, Nicol\u00e1s Maduro, said.\n\nIn {"uri": "2024-07-410628098", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "01:01:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T01:01:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T00:55:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/world/2024/0704/1458079-hurricane-beryl-jamaica/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl strikes Jamaica as death toll creeps to 9", "body": "Hurricane Beryl churned menacingly over Jamaica, after uprooting trees, ripping off roofs and destroying farms as it forged a destructive, water-soaked path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple days.\n\nThe death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane rose to at least nine, but it is widely expected to rise as communications come back online across drenched islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nIn Jamaica, the storm hit the island's southern coast, pummelling communities with intense wind and rain as emergency groups evacuated people living in flood-prone communities.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in Jamaica's southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nAlmost 500 Jamaicans were in shelters by Wednesday afternoon, Prime Minister Andrew Holness told reporters, urging people in high-risk areas to move.\n\n\"We have not seen the worst of what could happen,\" Mr Holness said. \"We can do as much as we can do, as (is) humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God.\"\n\nThe airports in the Jamaican capital, Kingston, and tourist-popular Montego Bay were closed throughout the day.\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a telltale sign of human-caused climate change fuelling extreme weather that differs from past experience.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one of the hardest-hit areas in the eastern Caribbean, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl.\n\n\"Everybody is homeless ... It is going to be a Herculean effort to rebuild,\" he added.\n\nSpeaking to state media, Nerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned of possible food shortages after 50% of the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nIn Kingston, streets were quiet as anxious residents hunkered down after spending the morning stocking up on essential supplies.\n\nJamaicans braced for electricity cuts, according to a power company official, with roads near the coastal ready washed out as steady rain continued to fall and winds picked up in the capital.\n\nIn St. Elizabeth, local politician Joseph Patterson said the power was out and the situation was \"getting gradually worse by the minute,\" with aggressive winds bringing down trees.\n\nBy Wednesday afternoon, the well-defined eye of the spiralling hurricane was located about 105km southeast of Kingston, according to the US National Hurricane Centre (NHC), though its outer rings were already lashing much of the island with a population of nearly 3 million.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 225km/h.\n\nThe force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl will remain at or near major hurricane strength as it moves on to the Cayman Islands.\n\n\"Life-threatening flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall are expected over much of Jamaica and southern Haiti through today,\" the NHC said in a post, adding that dangerous winds and storm surge are also expected in the Cayman Islands through early Thursday.\n\nThe centre added that a hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, as well as the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, including for the country's top beach resort Cancun.\n\nOvernight in Haiti as Beryl's impact grew progressively stronger, residents anxiously awaited its full impact.\n\n\"We were not comfortable. We could not sleep normally with the wind, the water. Many people slept in the yard,\" said Pouchon Jean-Francois, who lives in an improvised camp in Port-au-Prince.\n\nVenezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodriguez was injured as she surveyed an area south of Beryl, where the Manzanares River in Sucre state burst its banks.\n\nPresident Nicolas Maduro confirmed the injuries caused by a falling tree to his second-in-command, along with head injuries suffered by senior officials accompanying her, after intense rainfall struck inland from the country's Caribbean coastline.\n\nOn Tuesday night, Mr Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8,000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nThe unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fuelled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nAdditional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nBeyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn Cancun, officials said supplies of wooden boards used to protect doors and windows were dwindling as locals and tourists prepared for Beryl's arrival.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements once Network's hurricane hub for all the latest on the active hurricane season ahead\n\nNow, the still-dangerous, Category 4 hurricane is on its way to the Cayman Islands shortly and will then reach the Yucatan Peninsula Thursday night, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC).\n\nThose who have a flight scheduled for in or out of Jamaica, the Cayman Islands or other destinations in the "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/hurricane-beryl-leaves-jamaica-without-085820817.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl leaves Jamaica without power as it barrels towards Mexico", "body": "Hurricane Beryl powered towards Mexico late Wednesday, after battering Jamaica's southern coast with devastating winds and sea surge.\n\nThe Category 5 storm left a trail of destruction in its path across the Caribbean, killing at least seven people as it strengthened rapidly.\n\nBeryl pulled away from Jamaica late Wednesday and was expected to pass just south of the Cayman Islands overnight, before moving onward to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center (NHC) said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nMexican officials are scrambling to prepare, with Beryl expected to bring damaging winds, a dangerous storm surge and heavy rainfall over the Yucatan Peninsula and Belize.\n\n\"We will have intense rains and wind gusts\" from Thursday, Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for around 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo, where Beryl will likely hit.\n\nIn Jamaica, \"life-threatening flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall\" were still expected overnight, the NHC said.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power, according to the Jamaica Gleaner newspaper, citing a public service company.\n\nAndrew Holness, Jamaica's prime minister, declared a curfew from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff had scrambled to be ready.\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment - including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nAs of Wednesday night, Beryl was packing maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph), said the NHC.\n\nAt least three people were killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St Vincent and the Grenadines, said that it would take a \"herculean effort\" to rebuild after the substantial destruction and that \"90-odd per cent of the houses were blown away\" on Union Island.\n\n\"Most of the country doesn't have electricity, and more than half without water at the moment,\" he said.\n\nDickon Mitchell, Grenada's prime minister, said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 13.5-square mile (35-square km) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people died, Mitchell said, with a third killed in Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela's northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was damaged.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": intense wind and rain, causing floods and power outages after forging a destructive path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple of days.\n\nThe death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane climbed to at least 10 across the region, and is widely expected to rise further as communications return on islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nAs Beryl moved away from Jamaica early on Thursday, the island discontinued its hurricane warning but kept a flash flood watch, the Meteorological Service of Jamaica said on X.\n\nCheck out The Weather Network's hurricane hub for all {"uri": "8209863468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "16:19:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T16:19:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T16:19:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.caribbeannationalweekly.com/news/cat-3-hurricane-beryl-heads-toward-cayman-islands-mexico/", "title": "Cat. 3 Hurricane Beryl heads toward Cayman Islands, Mexico", "body": "Hurricane Beryl, which has wreaked havoc across Jamaica with damaging winds and heavy rain, left at least 11 people dead across the region. Now, the storm maintains its strength as it barrels past the Cayman Islands and heads toward Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula.\n\nAccording to the National Hurricane Center's 11 a.m. update, the center of Beryl is expected to move past the Cayman Islands on Thursday afternoon, bringing \"strong winds, dangerous storm surge, and damaging waves\" to the Yucatan Peninsula's coast early Friday. The hurricane, downgraded to a Category 3 early Thursday, had winds of 115 mph when it was about 95 miles west-southwest of Grand Cayman.\n\nThe Cayman Islands can expect up to six inches of rain on Thursday, while the Yucatan Peninsula could see up to 10 inches, potentially causing flash flooding.\n\nStorm surge warnings indicate water levels could rise by 2 to 4 feet along the Cayman Islands' immediate coast and 3 to 5 feet on the Yucatan's east coast, accompanied by \"large and destructive waves.\" Weather officials caution that Beryl will likely bring life-threatening surf and rip currents to the coasts of Jamaica, Cuba, and the Cayman Islands, with these dangers spreading to the Yucatan Peninsula and parts of Central America by Thursday and then to eastern Mexico and the U.S. Gulf Coast by late Friday.\n\nAs hurricane conditions subside in the Cayman Islands, tropical storm-strength winds are expected in the Yucatan Peninsula on Thursday. This will make outdoor preparations hazardous ahead of the storm's anticipated arrival later in the day or by early Friday.\n\nA hurricane warning is in effect for the Cayman Islands and the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun, including Cozumel. While Beryl is forecasted to weaken over the next two days, it is still projected to be near hurricane intensity when passing by the Cayman Islands on Thursday and heading toward the Yucatan Peninsula later in the day.\n\nJamaica experienced widespread power outages after Beryl brushed the island's southern coast on Wednesday as a Category 4 storm. The hurricane's destructive winds and rain have left a trail of devastation.\n\nOfficials confirmed that nine people were killed in Grenada, Venezuela, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines, according to Reuters. Jamaica's Prime Minister Andrew Holness told CNN on Thursday that two deaths have been registered in Jamaica due to Hurricane Beryl.\n\nA hurricane watch and tropical storm warning remain in effect for parts of the Yucatan Peninsula's coast. Mexico's government upgraded its tropical storm watch to a tropical storm warning from Progreso to Campeche. {"uri": "8209080501", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "07:41:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T07:41:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T07:41:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.stabroeknews.com/2024/07/04/news/world/hurricane-beryl-strikes-jamaica-as-caymans-mexico-brace-for-storms-impact/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl strikes Jamaica as Caymans, Mexico brace for storm's impact - Stabroek News", "body": "KINGSTON, (Reuters) - Hurricane Beryl thrashed Jamaica with heavy winds and rain yesterday, killing at least one person after forging a destructive, water-soaked path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple days.\n\nThe death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane climbed to at least 10, but it is widely expected to rise further as communications come back online across drenched islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nIn Jamaica, Beryl's eyewall skirted the island's southern coast, pummeling communities as emergency groups rushed to evacuate people from flood-prone areas.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in Jamaica's southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nA woman died in Jamaica's Hanover parish after a tree fell on her home, Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency said in an interview on local news.\n\nNearly a thousand Jamaicans were in shelters by last evening, Thompson added.\n\nThe island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a nationwide curfew for yesterday.\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as (is) humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said earlier yesterday, urging residents in vulnerable areas to evacuate.\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a telltale sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather that differs from past experience.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one of the hardest-hit areas in the eastern Caribbean, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl.\n\n\"Everybody is homeless ... It is going to be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nSpeaking to state media, Nerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned of possible food shortages after 50% of the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nPower outages were widespread across Jamaica, while some roads near the coast were washed out.\n\nBy last evening, the eye of the spiraling hurricane was located about 100 miles (161 km) west of Kingston, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC), as the storm's core headed toward the Cayman Islands, where hurricane conditions were expected late tonight.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 130 miles per hour (209 kph).\n\nThe force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in the next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl would remain at or near major hurricane strength as it passed the Cayman Islands.\n\nBeryl is expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands overnight and into today. Large swells were expected to \"cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions,\" the NHC said.\n\nThe center added that a hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, as well as the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, including for the country's top beach resort Cancun.\n\nAdditional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three din St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nIn Venezuela, President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8,000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nVenezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodriguez was injured by a falling tree on Tuesday as she surveyed an area south of Beryl where intense rainfall caused the Manzanares River in Sucre state to burst its banks, the president confirmed.\n\nThe unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fueled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nBeyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall as hurricane on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn the fishing village of Punta Allen, in the state of Quintana Roo, residents moved boats inland for safety, while navy officers implored reluctant residents to evacuate.\n\nIn tourist epicenter Cancun, an environmental agency worked to gather eggs from sea turtles' nests for their protection. Tourists soaked up the sun's rays while they still could.\n\nMeanwhile, workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection. Officials said supplies of wooden boards were dwindling as Cancun locals and tourists prepared for Beryl's arrival.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements once the hurricane approaches, in comments to local broadcaster Milenio.", "source": {"uri": "stabroeknews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8208550719", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "22:31:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T22:31:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T22:30:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.myjoyonline.com/powerful-hurricane-beryl-roars-towards-jamaica/", "title": "Powerful Hurricane Beryl roars towards Jamaica - MyJoyOnline", "body": "Jamaica is bracing for a powerful hurricane as it roars towards the Caribbean island.\n\nBeryl - a category four storm with winds near 140mph (220km/h) - is expected to pass near or over the southern coast in the next few hours, the US National Hurricane Center (NHC) warns.\n\nIt predicts \"life-threatening winds and storm surge\" in Jamaica as well as the Cayman Islands later.\n\nAt least seven people have been killed so far as the storm sweeps through the Caribbean.\n\nA hurricane warning is in effect in Jamaica, where the authorities have imposed a curfew from 06:00 to 18:00 local time (11:00-23:00 GMT).\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness urged people to \"take this hurricane seriously\".\n\n\"If you live in a low-lying area, an area historically prone to flooding and landslide, or if you live on the banks of a river or a gully, I implore you to evacuate to a shelter or to safer ground,\" he said.\n\nThree people died in Grenada, where it first made landfall on Monday, one in St Vincent and the Grenadines, and another three in northern Venezuela, which was hit by strong winds and flooding.\n\nAbout 90% of homes were destroyed or severely damaged on Union Island, which is part of St Vincent and the Grenadines.\n\nParts of Jamaica have experienced disruption to power and electricity supplies, with the Jamaica Public Service Company (JPS) saying it was forced to pause restoration of power lines in some locations for the safety of their workers.\n\nIn a news briefing, the NHC's director, Dr Michael Brennan, said Jamaica would experience \"devastating hurricane force winds\".\n\nRainfall in some parts of the country could hit 12in (30cm), potentially leading to flooding and mudslides, the director explained, while life-threatening storm surges as high as 9ft (2.7m) above tide level are also expected.\n\n\"Everybody in Jamaica needs to be in their safe place and be prepared to stay there for at least the next 12 hours,\" Dr Brennan warned.\n\nThe BBC's Nick Davis said Jamaicans had been rushing to supermarkets on Tuesday to get \"as much as they could as quickly as they could\".\n\nJamaica's Information Minister Dana Morris Dixon said the island had 900 shelters to house people who needed to leave their homes.\n\nIn Venezuela, Hurricane Beryl brought heavy rains which caused a river to overflow in the northern state of Sucre. Three people died and several are still missing.\n\nA government delegation was hit by a falling tree while inspecting damage.\n\nPresident Nicol\u00e1s Maduro said Vice-President Delcy Rodr\u00edguez was among those injured. He said she was \"very bruised but conscious\".\n\nIn Mexico, where Hurricane Beryl is expected in the coming days, residents in Canc\u00fan have rushed to supermarkets to stock up on supplies. Some have encountered empty shelves.\n\nThe NHC said that Hurricane Beryl was the earliest category five storm recorded in the Atlantic and had formed much earlier in the hurricane season than usual.\n\nMeteorologists have also remarked on how quickly Beryl developed.\n\nThe storm strengthened from a tropical depression into a major hurricane in 42 hours, hurricane expert Sam Lillo told the Associated Press news agency.\n\nIn Texas, officials warned residents to prepare for the possibility of Beryl's arrival this weekend.\n\nOn Tuesday, Governor Greg Abbott told resident's near the state's Atlantic coast to \"keep an eye on the gulf\" and \"have an emergency plan to take care of yourself and your loved ones\".\n\nThe US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has
