{"uri": "8208741084", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "02:40:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T02:40:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T02:39:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "http://www.seychellesnewsagency.com/articles/20824/Hurricane+Beryl+hammers+Jamaica+on+path+to+Caymans%2C+Mexico", "title": "Hurricane Beryl hammers Jamaica on path to Caymans, Mexico", "body": "Powerful Hurricane Beryl churned along Jamaica's southern coast on Wednesday, battering the island with dangerous winds and sea surge after leaving a trail of destruction and at least seven people dead in the Caribbean.\n\nThe eye of the Category 4 hurricane has not yet breached the shore of Jamaica but could in the coming hours, and is expected to approach or even make landfall in the Cayman islands overnight before moving onward to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nAhead of Beryl's arrival, people across Jamaica removed boats from the water and rushed to buy food, water, gasoline and other essentials.\n\nAs of Wednesday afternoon the storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 kph), said the NHC. Hurricane conditions are spreading through the island, it said.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness declared a curfew from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\n\"If you live in a low lying area, an area historically prone to flooding and landslide or if you live on the banks of a river, I implore you to evacuate to a shelter, or to safer ground,\" he said in a video posted to social media.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff has scrambled to be ready.\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment -- including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nMexican officials were meanwhile scrambling to prepare for Beryl, which is expected to hit somewhere between the well-known tourist hotspot of Tulum and the town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto, according to Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez.\n\nBeginning Thursday \"we will have intense rains and wind gusts\" she said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for some 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo where Beryl will hit.\n\n- 'No communication' -\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 13.5-square mile (35-square kilometer) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country's main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela's northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\n- Climate change -\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8209729105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "14:46:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T14:46:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T14:41:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/hurricane-beryl-soaks-jamaica-see-143720530.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl soaks Jamaica: See photos of the damage after Category 4 hurricane", "body": "Hurricane Beryl brushed the coast of Jamaica on Wednesday, bringing floods and damaging buildings and killing at least one person.\n\nJamaica was battered by Beryl throughout the day Wednesday. The outer bands lashed the Caribbean island nation Wednesday morning before the eyewall brushed the south coast of Jamaica in the mid-afternoon. Beryl was a Category 4 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 140 mph at the time.\n\nThe storm was projected to pound Jamaica with 4 to 8 inches of rain with localized amounts of 12 inches. Storm trackers captured waves up to 25 feet as Beryl made its way to Jamaica, which has a population of 3 million people. The center was 45 miles from the capital city of Kingston by mid-afternoon. One woman died after a tree fell on her home, said Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency. He also said nearly 1,000 residents were in shelters by Wednesday evening.\n\nBeryl made history by becoming the earliest category 4 and 5 hurricane on record and developed from a tropical storm into a major hurricane (winds of 111 mph or higher) in just over 12 hours. It first made landfall Monday on Grenada's Carriacou Island with wind speeds touching 150 mph.\n\nForecasters say Beryl is projected to approach the Cayman Islands before moving toward the Yucatan Peninsula on Thursday. It is expected to hit the mainland of Mexico late Sunday, and some models have it making landfall again in Texas.\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. {"uri": "8209612859", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "13:21:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T13:21:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T13:20:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/hurricane-beryl-heads-for-cayman-islands-mexico-after-striking-jamaica/2160570/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl heads for Cayman Islands, Mexico after striking Jamaica", "body": "Beryl's eyewall skirted Jamaica's southern coast, pummeling communities as a powerful Category 4 storm on the five-step Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, as emergency workers evacuated people from flood-prone areas.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nBeryl moved away from Jamaica early on Thursday. At around 1200 GMT, the Category 3 hurricane was 50 miles (80 km) from Grand Cayman and about 385 miles (620 km) off Tulum, Mexico, the U.S. National Hurricane Center said.\n\nBeryl was carrying top winds of 130 mph (209 kph), and was expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands, where life-threatening surf and rip currents were possible, the NHC said.\n\nA hurricane warning was in force for the Cayman Islands east coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.\n\nMexico's tourist centres of Cancun and the wider Yucatan peninsula lie in Beryl's predicted path. Cancun's airport was thronged with tourists hoping to catch last flights out before the storm arrives. Workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection.\n\nMexico's defense ministry opened around 120 storm shelters, and asked visitors to heed instructions on evacuation or other measures.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and at its peak earlier this week was the earliest Category 5 storm on record. A Category 5 hurricane brings winds of 157 mph (252 kph) or higher, capable of causing catastrophic damage including the destruction of homes and infrastructure.\n\nIn Jamaica the island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a curfew for Wednesday, which was extended to Thursday as storm conditions continued. At least one person was reported killed in the storm.\n\nNearly 1,000 people were in shelters by Wednesday evening, Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency said in an interview on local news.\n\nThe storm hit St. Vincent and the Grenadines earlier in the week. Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves said in a radio interview that Union Island was \"flattened\" and it would \"be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nThere were at least three confirmed fatalities and crop damage was widespread, senior officials told Reuters. Union Island suffered destruction of more than 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions after the storm made impact earlier in the week, with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nVenezuelan President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died, four were missing, and over 8,000 homes damaged.\n\nThe U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year. The season runs from the start of June to the end of November\n\nBeryl's destructive power, coming so early in the hurricane season, underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather.\n\n(Writing by Bernadette Baum and Brendan O'Boyle; Reporting by Zahra Burton in Kingston, Robertson Henry in St. Vincent; Additional reporting by Natalia Siniawski in Gdansk, David Alire Garcia and Brendan O'Boyle in Mexico City; Editing by Stephen Coates and Frances Kerry)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", {"uri": "8208694619", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "01:41:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T01:41:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T01:41:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.odt.co.nz/news/world/hurricane-wreaks-more-destruction-death-toll-mounts", "title": "Hurricane wreaks more destruction as death toll mounts", "body": "The death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane rose to at least nine, but it is widely expected to rise as communications come back online across drenched islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nIn Jamaica, the storm hit the island's southern coast on Wednesday afternoon, pummeling communities with intense wind and rain as emergency groups evacuated people living in flood-prone communities.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in Jamaica's southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nAlmost 500 Jamaicans were in shelters by Wednesday afternoon, Prime Minister Andrew Holness told reporters, urging people in high-risk areas to move.\n\n\"We have not seen the worst of what could happen,\" Holness said. \"We can do as much as we can do, as (is) humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God.\"\n\nThe airports in the Jamaican capital, Kingston, and tourist-popular Montego Bay were closed throughout the day.\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a telltale sign of human-caused climate change fuelling extreme weather that differs from past experience.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one of the hardest-hit areas in the eastern Caribbean, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl.\n\n\"Everybody is homeless ... It is going to be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nSpeaking to state media, Nerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned of possible food shortages after 50% of the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nIn Kingston, streets were quiet as anxious residents hunkered down after spending the morning stocking up on essential supplies.\n\nJamaicans braced for electricity cuts later on Wednesday, according to a power company official, with roads near the coast already washed out as steady rain continued to fall and winds picked up in the capital.\n\nIn St. Elizabeth, local politician Joseph Patterson said the power was out and the situation was \"getting gradually worse by the minute,\" with aggressive winds bringing down trees.\n\nBy Wednesday afternoon, the well-defined eye of the spiralling hurricane was located about 105km southeast of Kingston, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC), though its outer rings were already lashing much of the island with a population of nearly 3 million.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 225kmh.\n\nThe force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl will remain at or near major hurricane strength as it moves on to the Cayman Islands.\n\n\"Life-threatening flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall are expected over much of Jamaica and southern Haiti through today,\" the NHC said in a post, adding that dangerous winds and storm surge are also expected in the Cayman Islands through early Thursday.\n\nOvernight in Haiti as Beryl's impact grew progressively stronger, residents anxiously awaited its full impact.\n\n\"We were not comfortable. We could not sleep normally with the wind, the water. Many people slept in the yard,\" said Pouchon Jean-Francois, who lives in an improvised camp in Port-au-Prince.\n\nVenezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodriguez was injured as she surveyed an area south of Beryl on Tuesday night, where the Manzanares River in Sucre state burst its banks.\n\nPresident Nicolas Maduro confirmed the injuries caused by a falling tree to his second-in-command, along with head injuries suffered by senior officials accompanying her, after intense rainfall struck inland from the country's Caribbean coastline.\n\nOn Tuesday night, Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nThe unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fueled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nAdditional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nBeyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn Cancun, officials said supplies of wooden boards used to protect doors and windows were dwindling as locals and tourists prepared for Beryl's arrival.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements once {"uri": "8209787645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "15:25:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T15:25:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T15:22:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/where-hurricane-beryl-now-storm-150319786.html", "title": "Where is Hurricane Beryl now? Storm weakens Thursday as path continues toward South Texas", "body": "Hurricane Beryl is bringing strong winds and dangerous storm surges to the Cayman Islands after slamming Jamaica on Wednesday as a Category 4 storm with 140-mph winds.\n\nBeryl was downgraded to a Category 3 hurricane early Thursday and is forecast to weaken gradually as it heads toward the Yucatan Peninsula by late Thursday. A hurricane warning is in effect for the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico from Puerto Costa Maya to Cancun, including Cozumel.\n\nThe National Weather Service office in Corpus Christi said on Wednesday afternoon that \"it is looking more likely that Beryl will make landfall across far northeast Mexico or the South Texas Coast\" as a Category 1 hurricane early next week. Authorities still advise to prepare for the event as if it's a Category 2 storm.\n\nMore: As Hurricane Beryl moves through the Caribbean, Corpus Christi prepares for possible hit\n\nThe center of Hurricane Beryl was located near latitude 18.7 North, longitude 81.8 West, according to the National Hurricane Center's latest advisory.\n\nBeryl is moving toward the west-northwest near 20 mph. A westward to west- northwestward motion is expected during the next day or two, taking the core of Beryl away from the Cayman Islands this morning and over the Yucatan Peninsula early Friday.\n\nBeryl is expected to emerge over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico Friday night and turn northwestward.\n\nHurricane Beryl tracker: Maps show storm's projected path as it heads toward South Texas\n\nThe impact on northeastern Mexico and southern Texas will depend on how much Beryl strengthens over the Gulf and its speed when it arrives.\n\nIn recent days, Beryl's wind field has increased, extending up to 185 miles from the center and bringing South Texas -- from Brownsville to Corpus Christi -- into the edge of the storm's impact.\n\n\"From Panama City, to New Orleans, there is a low risk of direct impacts from Beryl, but from about Corpus Christi to Brownsville, Texas, the risk increases significantly due to the potential for Beryl to have more direct impacts,\" AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jonathan Porter said.\n\n\"That southern portion of the Texas coast is the zone we have to really watch,\" he added.\n\nMore: History-making Hurricane Beryl likely to hit South Texas as Cat 1 storm next week, NWS says\n\nGov. Greg Abbott issued an advisory notice warning the state's emergency management agencies to prepare for storm response and recovery efforts as Hurricane Beryl's path shifts toward South Texas.\n\n\"As Texans around the south coastal areas make holiday plans and visitors begin to travel for the holiday weekend, I urge them to take necessary safety precautions, remain weather aware, and have an emergency plan ready for themselves and their families.\" the advisory said.\n\n\"State and local officials will continue to work around-the-clock to monitor statewide weather conditions and help protect Texans.\"\n\nThis forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\n-- USA TODAY contributed to this Chances of development of this system are low through the next seven days.\n\nAs of the National Hurricane Center's 8 a.m. advisory, the center of Hurricane Beryl was located near latitude 18.7 North, longitude 81.8 West.\n\nBeryl is moving toward the west-northwest near 20 mph. A westward to west- northwestward motion is expected during the next day or two, taking the core of Beryl away from the Cayman Islands this morning and over the Yucatan Peninsula early Friday. Beryl is expected to emerge over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico Friday night and turn northwestward.\n\nReports from a NOAA Hurricane Hunter aircraft indicate that maximum sustained winds are near 120 mph with higher gusts. Beryl is a Category 3 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. Weakening is forecast during the next day or two, though Beryl is forecast to remain a hurricane until it makes landfall on the Yucatan Peninsula.\n\nHurricane-force winds extend outward up to 45 miles from the center and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 175 miles. Grand Cayman Island recently reported sustained winds of 44 mph and a wind gust of 54 mph.\n\n\u27a4 Hurricane Beryl path\n\nCould Hurricane Beryl affect Florida, US Gulf Coast?\n\nInvest 96L\n\nInvest 96L: A fast-moving tropical wave located over the eastern Caribbean Sea is producing some disorganized shower and thunderstorm activity.\n\nDevelopment, if any, of this system should be slow to occur while it moves quickly westward to west-northwestward at 20 to 25 mph across the Caribbean Sea through this weekend.\n\nThe system is forecast to cross the Yucatan Peninsula and enter the southwestern Gulf of Mexico by early next week where some development could occur.\n\nGusty winds and locally heavy rainfall are possible across portions of the Greater Antilles over the next few days.\n\n\u27a4 Track 96L:Spaghetti models for Invest 96L\n\nWho is likely to be impacted?\n\nHurricane Beryl: There remains uncertainty in the track and intensity forecast of Beryl over the western Gulf of Mexico this weekend. {"uri": "8208593022", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "23:27:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T23:27:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T23:26:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/hurricane-beryl-hammers-jamaica-on-path-to-caymans-mexico/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl hammers Jamaica on path to Caymans, Mexico | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "Powerful Hurricane Beryl churned along Jamaica's southern coast on Wednesday, battering the island with dangerous winds and sea surge after leaving a trail of destruction and at least seven people dead in the Caribbean.\n\nThe eye of the Category 4 hurricane has not yet breached the shore of Jamaica but could in the coming hours, and is expected to approach or even make landfall in the Cayman islands overnight before moving onward to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nAhead of Beryl's arrival, people across Jamaica removed boats from the water and rushed to buy food, water, gasoline and other essentials.\n\nAs of Wednesday afternoon the storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 kph), said the NHC. Hurricane conditions are spreading through the island, it said.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness declared a curfew from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\n\"If you live in a low lying area, an area historically prone to flooding and landslide or if you live on the banks of a river, I implore you to evacuate to a shelter, or to safer ground,\" he said in a video posted to social media.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff has scrambled to be ready.\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment -- including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nMexican officials were meanwhile scrambling to prepare for Beryl, which is expected to hit somewhere between the well-known tourist hotspot of Tulum and the town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto, according to Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez.\n\nBeginning Thursday \"we will have intense rains and wind gusts\" she said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for some 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo where Beryl will hit.\n\n- 'No communication' -\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 13.5-square mile (35-square kilometer) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country's main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela's northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\n- Climate change -\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was damaged.\n\nbur-dw-bfm/des\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 28 Spokane"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ivan_shaw@fox28spokane.com", "name": Chances of development of this system are low through the next seven days.\n\nAs of the National Hurricane Center's 8 a.m. advisory, the center of Hurricane Beryl was located near latitude 18.7 North, longitude 81.8 West.\n\nBeryl is moving toward the west-northwest near 20 mph. A westward to west- northwestward motion is expected during the next day or two, taking the core of Beryl away from the Cayman Islands this morning and over the Yucatan Peninsula early Friday. Beryl is expected to emerge over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico Friday night and turn northwestward.\n\nReports from a NOAA Hurricane Hunter aircraft indicate that maximum sustained winds are near 120 mph with higher gusts. Beryl is a Category 3 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. Weakening is forecast during the next day or two, though Beryl is forecast to remain a hurricane until it makes landfall on the Yucatan Peninsula.\n\nHurricane-force winds extend outward up to 45 miles from the center and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 175 miles. per hour, and was expected to weaken further as it headed toward landfall overnight Thursday into Friday on the peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center said.\n\nAs of midday Thursday it was in the Caribbean about 530 kilometers east of Tulum, which is a about a two-hour drive from Cancun -- the two main resort cities in the region.\n\nThe storm already left a trail of destruction across the Caribbean and the coast of Venezuela, killing at least seven people and bringing with it flash floods and mudslides.\n\nIn Mexico, classes in the area bracing for a hit were suspended and shelters were set up for locals and tourists alike.\n\nIn Cancun, people have been stocking up on food and other essentials for days and hotels have boarded up their windows.\n\nBeryl is expected to slam the {"uri": "8208605688", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "23:44:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T23:44:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T23:43:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/americas/article/3269092/hurricane-beryl-hammers-jamaica-path-caymans-mexico", "title": "Hurricane Beryl hammers Jamaica on path to Caymans, Mexico", "body": "The powerful storm continues on its trail of destruction, after leaving at least seven dead in the Caribbean\n\nPowerful Hurricane Beryl churned along Jamaica\u2019s southern coast on Wednesday, battering the island with dangerous winds and sea surge after leaving a trail of destruction and at least seven people dead in the Caribbean.\n\nThe eye of the Category 4 hurricane has not yet breached the shore of Jamaica but could in the coming hours, and is expected to approach or even make landfall in the Cayman Islands overnight before moving onwards to Mexico\u2019s Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Centre said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nAhead of Beryl\u2019s arrival, people across Jamaica removed boats from the water and rushed to buy food, water, petrol and other essentials.\n\nAs of Wednesday afternoon the storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 220k/h (140mph), the NHC said. Hurricane conditions are spreading through the island, it said.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness declared a curfew from 6am to 6pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\n\u201cIf you live in a low lying area, an area historically prone to flooding and landslide or if you live on the banks of a river, I implore you to evacuate to a shelter, or to safer ground,\u201d he said in a video posted to social media.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff has scrambled to be ready.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve taped up our windows, covered our equipment \u2013 including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it\u2019s mainly concrete so there\u2019s not much we can do,\u201d Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nMexican officials were meanwhile scrambling to prepare for Beryl, which is expected to hit somewhere between the well-known tourist hotspot of Tulum and the town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto, according to Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez.\n\nBeginning on Thursday \u201cwe will have intense rains and wind gusts\u201d she said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for some 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo where Beryl will hit.\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall on Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nGrenada\u2019s Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 35 sq km (13.5 square mile) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country\u2019s main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela\u2019s northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between 2 and 5 degrees Fahrenheit (1 to3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate {"uri": "8209338382", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:24:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:24:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:23:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.nbcdfw.com/weather/weather-connection/texas-family-grenada-hurricane-beryl/3583404/", "title": "Texas family on vacation in Grenada describes riding out Hurricane Beryl", "body": "A family from Houston hunkered down inside a resort as the 'beast' of a storm initially made landfall in Grenada.\n\nThe historic Hurricane Beryl continues to barrel its way through the Caribbean. It's the first hurricane of the season and is the strongest storm, a Category 5, to form in the Atlantic so early in the hurricane season.\n\nJamaica, Grand Cayman, Little Cayman, and Cayman Brac currently have hurricane warnings as Beryl approaches those islands. At least six people have died across the Caribbean Sea. Rescue crews in the southeastern islands continue to determine the extent of the damage the hurricane inflicted on Carriacou, an island in Grenada.\n\nWhen Hurricane Beryl made landfall on Grenada, it was a Category 4. The deadly winds, flooding, and storm surge damaged many buildings and, according to the prime minister, caused the power to go out.\n\nA family from Houston was on vacation in the southeast part of the island, and they weathered the storm inside a resort.\n\n\"It felt like, 'Uh-oh, where am I going to go?' That's one thing that's comforting about the United States: You can always escape,\" said Hany Elqutub.\n\nElqutub, his wife, daughter and two grandchildren had been there for a week when the storm hit.\n\n\"We came here enjoying our time for the first couple of days, and then suddenly, the news came out about this beast, and it was a scary experience; yet, being from Houston, we've lived it, we've seen it,\" said Elqutub.\n\nElqutub recorded video showing when Hurricane Beryl began to make landfall. As the wind intensified, the water had more white caps.\n\n\"It was a big beast. I mean, it was really windy. I mean, you could see the sea going so mad, the waves and the surge was so high and it was extremely windy,\" described Elqutub.\n\nHe said he was grateful they were in a concrete resort with food, water, and a generator because he knew it was a different story for the locals.\n\n\"We are fortunate to be in this place. The rest of the island population had to go through a rough time, and I feel for them,\" said Elqutub.\n\nAccording to the National Hurricane Center, Hurricane Beryl is expected to hit Jamaica on Wednesday. It's expected to bring \"devastating hurricane-force winds, life-threatening storm surge and damaging waves.\"\n\nThe storm was expected to arrive in the Cayman Islands Wednesday night.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-411144982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "11:09:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T11:09:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T11:00:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2024-07-04-hurricane-beryl-steams-towards-cayman-islands-mexico-after-striking-jamaica/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl steams towards Cayman Islands, Mexico after striking Jamaica", "body": "KINGSTON, July 4 (Reuters) - Hurricane Beryl steamed towards the Cayman Islands and Mexico on Thursday, after thrashing Jamaica with intense wind and rain, causing floods and power outages after forging a destructive path across smaller Caribbean islands over the past couple of days.\n\nThe death toll from the powerful Category 4 hurricane climbed to at least 10 across the region, and is widely expected to rise further as communications return on islands damaged by flooding and deadly winds.\n\nAs Beryl moved away from Jamaica early on Thursday, the island discontinued its hurricane warning but kept a flash flood watch, the Meteorological Service of Jamaica said on X.\n\nBy late Wednesday, the storm's eye was about 100 miles (161 km) west of Kingston, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC), as its core headed toward the Cayman Islands.\n\nPacking maximum sustained winds of 130 miles per hour (209 kph), Beryl was expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands into Thursday, where a hurricane warning was in effect and life-threatening surf and rip currents were possible, NHC said.\n\nA hurricane warning was also in force for the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.\n\nAround 0900 GMT, the Category 3 hurricane was just 55 miles from Grand Cayman and about 440 miles off Tulum Mexico, NHC said.\n\nJAMAICA\n\nBeryl's eyewall skirted Jamaica's southern coast, pummeling communities as emergency groups evacuated people from flood-prone areas.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" said Amoy Wellington, a 51-year-old cashier who lives in Top Hill, a rural farming community in southern St. Elizabeth parish. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nA woman died in Jamaica's Hanover parish after a tree fell on her home, Richard Thompson, acting director general at Jamaica's disaster agency said in an interview on local news.\n\nNearly a thousand Jamaicans were in shelters by Wednesday evening, Thompson added.\n\nThe island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a curfew for Wednesday, which was extended Thursday as storm conditions continued.\n\nWARMING OCEAN\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a sign of human-caused climate change fueling extreme weather.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl and that it would \"be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nNerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned on state media of possible food shortages after half the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nPower outages were widespread across Jamaica, while some roads near the coast were washed out.\n\n'ARMAGEDDON-LIKE'\n\nConfirmed fatalities included at least three in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island suffered destruction of more than 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nIn Venezuela, President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing, with over 8,000 homes damaged.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record. The U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nIn tourist epicenter Cancun, workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection and officials said supplies of wooden boards were dwindling.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements as the storm approached, in comments to local broadcaster Milenio.\n\n(Reporting by Zahra Burton in Kingston, Harold Isaac in Port-au-Prince and Robertson Henry in St. Vincent; Additional reporting by David Alire Garcia and Brendan O'Boyle in Mexico City, Paola Chiomante in Punta Allen, Deisy Buitrago in Caracas and Natalia Siniawski in Gdansk; Writing by Sharon Singleton and Brendan O'Boyle; Editing by Sandra Maler, Stephen Coates and Bernadette Baum)", "source": {"uri": "dailymaverick.co.za", "dataType": {"uri": "8209349066", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:32:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:32:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:31:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/hurricane-beryl-lashes-cayman-islands-on-path-toward-mexico/82678569", "title": "Hurricane Beryl Lashes Cayman Islands on Path Toward Mexico", "body": "(Bloomberg) -- Hurricane Beryl roared toward the Cayman Islands with strong winds and ocean surge, after the brunt of the deadly storm passed Jamaica.\n\nThe eye of the Category 3 hurricane, downgraded from Category 4 earlier on Thursday, is nearing Grand Cayman as it pushes westward, lashing the islands with winds of 120 miles (195 kilometers) per hour.\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of destruction through the Caribbean, and earlier this week its winds topped the five-step Saffir-Simpson scale, achieving rare Category 5 strength. It was the earliest Atlantic storm to do so, signaling an unusually active hurricane season as hot ocean waters fuel tropical systems.\n\nThe storm surge swamping the coast could reach up to 4 feet on the Cayman Islands, and there were forecasts of as much as 6 inches of rain there. Heavy precipitation will continue in Jamaica through the morning, with flash flooding and mudslides possible.\n\nBeryl may also cause damage to oil installations as the US Gulf coast is on its potential path. Valero Energy Corp., Citgo Petroleum Corp. and Flint Hills Resources LLC all have refineries in the Corpus Christi area.\n\n\"I am encouraging all Jamaicans to take the hurricane as a serious threat,\" Prime Minister Andrew Holness said. \"It is, however, not a time for panic. It is a time for us to be very strategic and calculated in our approach.\"\n\nThe Associated Press reported at least six deaths as the hurricane raged across the southeast Caribbean. After Beryl sweeps south of the Cayman Islands, it is forecast to make landfall on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula Friday, where a hurricane warning has been posted.\n\nConditions in the Yucatan will likely start to deteriorate Thursday, with torrential rains, strong winds, and crashing surf raking the region, according to the National Meteorological Service of Mexico.\n\nShell Plc is evacuating non-essential personnel and shutting in production from its Perdido deepwater oil platform in the Gulf of Mexico as a precaution, according to a company statement.\n\nThough earlier models had the storm edging into the northern Gulf of Mexico after hitting the Yucatan, AccuWeather meteorologist Tyler Roys said it will likely make its final landfall in northern Mexico or even near Brownsville, Texas by late Sunday or early Monday.\n\nWhile the humanitarian losses are still being assessed, there are signs Beryl is having an impact on markets.\n\nBeryl made landfall Monday on Carriacou, the second-largest of Grenada's islands. The electricity and communications system has been completely destroyed and the island's marina -- the heart of its tourism industry -- was also significantly damaged, Grenada Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said in a national address.\n\n\"It is going to be a mammoth task to rebuild,\" Mitchell said.\n\n-With assistance from Jim Wyss, Megan Durisin, Amanda Jordan, Atul Prakash and Jack At least seven are dead in the eastern Caribbean, where Beryl first made landfall on Monday and leveled some small islands with \"98% destruction.\"\n\nEven the outermost bands of Beryl were enough to cause power outages and road closures in the Dominican Republic, but the harder hit was on Jamaica's southern coast, which got brushed by the northern eyewall of the at-the-time Category 4 hurricane.\n\nJamaicans woke up Thursday to downed power lines in Portmore, trees blocking the highway in Manchester and in south St. Elizabeth: knee-high flood waters, wet furniture and ripped-off roofs.\n\nHurricane Beryl left a trail of destruction in southern parishes where Machester and St. Elizabeth bore the brunt of Beryl's powerful winds and rain before the hurricane warning was lifted shortly before midnight and a flash flood watch went into effect.\n\nPart of the roof of the Norman Manley International Airport near Kingston was ripped off, along with roofs of homes and buildings nearby. Around 400,000 customers were without electricity overnight Wednesday, the Jamaica Public Service Company told the Jamaica Gleaner.\n\nNext stop: Mexico\n\nAs of the 8 a.m. update, Beryl was packing 120 mph sustained winds and headed west-northwest at 20 mph. It was about 385 miles east-southeast of Tulum, Mexico.\n\nThe latest forecast track from the National Hurricane Center steers Beryl over the Yucatan and into the Gulf of Mexico, where it's expected to re-strengthen a bit before making yet another landfall as a Category 1 hurricane near the border of Mexico and Texas.\n\n\"While the hurricane has been an over-performer so far, this magnitude of "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/mexico-girds-for-hit-from-hurricane-beryl/", "title": "Mexico girds for hit from Hurricane Beryl | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "Tourist resorts in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula girded Thursday for a hit from Hurricane Beryl, which is still packing ferocious winds after slamming Jamaica and then the Cayman Islands.\n\nBeryl dropped to a Category 3 storm, with winds of 185 kilometers (115 miles) per hour, and was expected to weaken further as it headed toward landfall overnight Thursday into Friday on the peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center said.\n\nAs of midday Thursday it was in the Caribbean about 530 kilometers east of Tulum, which is a about a two-hour drive from Cancun -- the two main resort cities in the region.\n\nThe storm already left a trail of destruction across the Caribbean and the coast of Venezuela, killing at least seven people and bringing with it flash floods and mudslides.\n\nIn Mexico, classes in the area bracing for a hit were suspended and shelters were set up for locals and tourists alike.\n\nIn Cancun, people have been stocking up on food and other essentials for days and hotels have boarded up their windows.\n\nBeryl is expected to slam the Yucatan as a Category 1 hurricane, emerge over the Gulf of Mexico, then hit the northern state of Tamaulipas, which borders the United States.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nIn the Cayman Islands, Acting Deputy Governor Eric Bush said there have been no calls for evacuations and expressed worry that some people were leaving their homes to film the storm, the Cayman Compass news website said.\n\nIn Jamaica, more than 400,000 people were without power, according to the Jamaica Gleaner newspaper, citing a public service company.\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was damaged.\n\nbur-dw/mlm\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-410778445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "05:22:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T05:22:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T05:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/644010/World/America/Hurricane-Beryl-batters-south-coast-of-Jamaica", "title": "Hurricane Beryl batters south coast of Jamaica", "body": "KINGSTON -- A powerful hurricane has hit Jamaica with heavy winds and rain, damaging buildings and felling trees on the Caribbean island.\n\nBeryl - a category four storm with winds of up to 130mph (215km/h) - struck the island's southern coast.\n\nPhotos on social media show flooded streets and roofs being blown up.\n\nAt least seven people have been killed so far as the storm sweeps through the Caribbean.\n\n\"It's terrible. Everything's gone. I'm in my house and scared,\" Amoy Wellington, resident of a rural farming community in the southern St Elizabeth parish, was quoted as saying by Reuters news agency. \"It's a disaster.\"\n\nA hurricane warning is in effect in Jamaica, where the authorities have imposed a curfew from 06:00 to 18:00 local time (11:00-23:00 GMT).\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness earlier urged people to \"take this hurricane seriously\".\n\n\"If you live in a low-lying area, an area historically prone to flooding and landslide, or if you live on the banks of a river or a gully, I implore you to evacuate to a shelter or to safer ground,\" he said.\n\nThree people died in Grenada, where it first made landfall on Monday, one in St Vincent and the Grenadines, and another three in northern Venezuela, which was hit by strong winds and flooding.\n\nAbout 90% of homes were destroyed or severely damaged on Union Island, which is part of St Vincent and the Grenadines.\n\nParts of Jamaica earlier experienced disruption to power and electricity supplies, with the Jamaica Public Service Company (JPS) saying it was forced to pause restoration of power lines in some locations for the safety of their workers.\n\nIn a news briefing, the NHC's director, Dr Michael Brennan, said Jamaica would experience \"devastating hurricane force winds\".\n\nRainfall in some parts of the country could hit 12in (30cm), potentially leading to flooding and mudslides, the director explained, while life-threatening storm surges as high as 9ft (2.7m) above tide level are also expected.\n\n\"Everybody in Jamaica needs to be in their safe place and be prepared to stay there for at least the next 12 hours,\" Dr Brennan warned.\n\nThe BBC's Nick Davis said Jamaicans had been rushing to supermarkets earlier in the week to get \"as much as they could as quickly as they could\".\n\nJamaica's Information Minister Dana Morris Dixon said the island had 900 shelters to house people who needed to leave their homes.\n\nIn Venezuela, Hurricane Beryl brought heavy rains which caused a river to overflow in the northern state of Sucre. Three people died and several are still missing.\n\nA government delegation was hit by a falling tree while inspecting damage.\n\nPresident Nicol\u00e1s Maduro said Vice-President Delcy Rodr\u00edguez was among those injured. He said she was \"very bruised but conscious\".\n\nIn Mexico, where Hurricane Beryl is expected in the coming days, residents in Canc\u00fan have rushed to supermarkets to stock up on supplies. Some have encountered empty shelves.\n\nThe NHC said that Hurricane Beryl had formed much earlier in the hurricane season than usual.\n\nMeteorologists have also remarked on how quickly Beryl developed.\n\nThe storm strengthened from a tropical depression into a major hurricane in 42 hours, hurricane expert Sam Lillo told the Associated Press news agency.\n\nIn Texas, officials warned residents to prepare for the possibility of Beryl's arrival this weekend.\n\nOn Tuesday, Governor Greg Abbott told residents near the state's Atlantic coast to \"keep an eye on the gulf\" and \"have an emergency plan to take care of yourself and your loved ones\".\n\nThe US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has warned that the North Atlantic could get as many as seven major {"uri": "2024-07-410609342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "00:17:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T00:17:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T22:34:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/hurricane-beryl-hammers-jamaica-on-path-to-caymans-mexico/article_c8926620-3c42-52af-b209-e1372d6222cc.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl hammers Jamaica on path to Caymans, Mexico", "body": "Powerful Hurricane Beryl churned along Jamaica's southern coast on Wednesday, battering the island with dangerous winds and sea surge after leaving a trail of destruction and at least seven people dead in the Caribbean.\n\nThe eye of the Category 4 hurricane has not yet breached the shore of Jamaica but could in the coming hours, and is expected to approach or even make landfall in the Cayman islands overnight before moving onward to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nAhead of Beryl's arrival, people across Jamaica removed boats from the water and rushed to buy food, water, gasoline and other essentials.\n\nAs of Wednesday afternoon the storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 kph), said the NHC. Hurricane conditions are spreading through the island, it said.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness declared a curfew from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\n\"If you live in a low lying area, an area historically prone to flooding and landslide or if you live on the banks of a river, I implore you to evacuate to a shelter, or to safer ground,\" he said in a video posted to social media.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff has scrambled to be ready.\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment -- including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nMexican officials were meanwhile scrambling to prepare for Beryl, which is expected to hit somewhere between the well-known tourist hotspot of Tulum and the town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto, according to Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez.\n\nBeginning Thursday \"we will have intense rains and wind gusts\" she said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for some 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo where Beryl will hit.\n\n- 'No communication' -\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 13.5-square mile (35-square kilometer) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country's main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela's northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\n- Climate change -\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was damaged.\n\nbur-dw-bfm/des\n\nMore from this section\n\n'Artificial Wisdom' is a smash hit!\n\nCharles Symington is the New President of Primum Familiae Vini\n\nTeal in Top Best Managed Service {"uri": "8208859968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "04:46:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T04:46:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T04:45:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/world/2024-07-04-hurricane-beryl-strikes-jamaica-as-caymans-mexico-brace-for-storms-impact/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl strikes Jamaica as Caymans, Mexico brace for storm's impact", "body": "The island's main airports were closed and streets were mostly empty after Prime Minister Andrew Holness issued a nationwide curfew for Wednesday.\n\n\"We can do as much as we can do, as (is) humanly possible, and we leave the rest in the hands of God,\" Holness said earlier on Wednesday, urging residents in vulnerable areas to evacuate.\n\nThe loss of life and damage wrought by Beryl underscores the consequences of a warmer Atlantic Ocean, which scientists cite as a telltale sign of human-caused climate change fuelling extreme weather that differs from past experience.\n\nRalph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one of the hardest-hit areas in the eastern Caribbean, said in a radio interview that the country's Union Island was \"flattened\" by Beryl.\n\n\"Everybody is homeless ... It is going to be a Herculean effort to rebuild.\"\n\nSpeaking to state media, Nerissa Gittens-McMillan, permanent secretary at St. Vincent and the Grenadines' agriculture ministry, warned of possible food shortages after 50% of the country's plantain and banana crops were lost, with significant losses also to root crops and vegetables.\n\nPower outages were widespread across Jamaica, while some roads near the coast were washed out.\n\nBy Wednesday evening, the eye of the spiralling hurricane was located about 100 miles (161km) west of Kingston, according to the US National Hurricane Center (NHC), as the storm's core headed towards the Cayman Islands, where hurricane conditions were expected late tonight.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 130 miles per hour (209kph).\n\nThe force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in the next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl would remain at or near major hurricane strength as it passed the Cayman Islands.\n\nBeryl is expected to dump 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) of rain on the Cayman Islands overnight and into Thursday. Large swells were expected to \"cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions,\" the NHC said.\n\nThe centre added that a hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, as well as the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, including for the country's top beach resort Cancun.\n\n'ARMAGEDDON-LIKE'\n\nAdditional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three din St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nIn Venezuela, President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8,000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nVenezuelan vice-president Delcy Rodriguez was injured by a falling tree on Tuesday as she surveyed an area south of Beryl where intense rainfall caused the Manzanares River in Sucre state to burst its banks, the president confirmed.\n\nThe unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fuelled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nBeyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall as hurricane on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn the fishing village of Punta Allen, in the state of Quintana Roo, residents moved boats inland for safety, while navy officers implored reluctant residents to evacuate.\n\nIn tourist epicentre Cancun, an environmental agency worked to gather eggs from sea turtles' nests for their protection. Tourists soaked up the sun's rays while they still could.\n\nMeanwhile, workers filled bags with sand and boarded up doors and windows of businesses for protection. Officials said supplies of wooden boards were dwindling as Cancun locals and tourists prepared for Beryl's arrival.\n\nLaura Velazquez, head of Mexico's civil protection agency, encouraged tourists in Cancun and nearby Tulum to hunker down in hotel basements once the hurricane approaches, in comments to local broadcaster Milenio.", "source": {"uri": "timeslive.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8208584350", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "23:15:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T23:15:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T23:14:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/hurricane-beryl-strikes-jamaica-as-toll-rises-to-nine/5CRDCX74MZGP3AKHS3DETITUF4/", "title": "'Everything is destroyed': Hurricane strikes Jamaica", "body": "In the Jamaican capital, Kingston, anxious motorists lined up at petrol stations, as others stocked up on essential supplies.\n\n\"It is imperative that we remain calm,\" said Prime Minister Andrew Holness in a national address late on Tuesday. \"Now's not a time to panic.\"\n\nJamaicans braced for electricity cuts later on Wednesday, according to a power company official, with roads near the coast already washed out as a steady rain continued to fall and winds picked up in the capital.\n\nBy midday on Wednesday, the well-defined eye of the spiralling hurricane was located about 72km southeast of Kingston, according to the US National Hurricane Center (NHC), though its outer rings were already lashing much of the island with a population of nearly three million.\n\nBeryl is packing maximum sustained winds of 225km/h.\n\nThe force of the winds is expected to weaken somewhat in next day or two, according to the NHC, though it cautioned that Beryl will remain at or near major hurricane strength as it moves on to the Cayman Islands.\n\n\"Life-threatening flash flooding and mudslides from heavy rainfall are expected over much of Jamaica and southern Haiti through today,\" the NHC said in a post, adding that dangerous winds and storm surge are also expected in the Cayman Islands through early Thursday.\n\nThe centre added that a hurricane warning was in effect for Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, as well as the eastern coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, including for the country's top beach resort Cancun.\n\nOvernight in Haiti as Beryl's impact grew progressively stronger, residents anxiously awaited its full impact.\n\n\"We were not comfortable. We could not sleep normally with the wind, the water. Many people slept in the yard,\" said Pouchon Jean-Francois, who lives in an improvised camp in Port-au-Prince.\n\nVenezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodriguez was injured as she surveyed an area south of Beryl on Tuesday night, where the Manzanares River in Sucre state burst its banks.\n\nOn Tuesday night, President Nicolas Maduro told state television that three people had died and four were missing in the area, along with more than 8000 homes damaged by torrential rains, including at least 400 destroyed.\n\nThe unusually early hurricane strengthened at a record pace, which scientists argue is almost certainly fuelled by climate change.\n\nBeryl is the 2024 Atlantic season's first hurricane and the earliest storm on record to reach the highest category on the Saffir-Simpson five-stage scale. The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has forecast a large number of major hurricanes in an \"extraordinary\" season this year.\n\nAdditional confirmed fatalities so far include at least three in St Vincent and the Grenadines, a senior official told Reuters, where Union Island has suffered severe destruction of over 90% of buildings.\n\nIn Grenada, Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell described \"Armageddon-like\" conditions with no power and widespread destruction, while also confirming three deaths.\n\nBeyond near-term impact in Jamaica and Haiti, the NHC warned that Beryl will likely make landfall on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as early as Thursday night.\n\nIn Cancun, officials said supplies of wooden boards used to protect doors and windows were dwindling after killing six in Caribbean", "body": "Hurricane Beryl is hurtling towards Jamaica and is expected to make landfall in the next few hours, as ITV News correspondent Geraint Vincent reports\n\nHurricane Beryl is roaring past Jamaica after killing at least six people in the south-east Caribbean earlier this week.\n\nThe storm is expected to generate a \"life-threatening storm surge\" and dangerous winds in portions of Jamaica and the Cayman Islands, according to the National Hurricane Centre.\n\nJamaica has been placed under a state of emergency for the next seven says, with Prime Minister Andrew Holness announcing an island-wide curfew between 6am and 6pm local time on Wednesday.\n\nIt is now considered a very strong Category 4 hurricane, with winds of 150 mph.\n\nThe Prince and Princess of Wales are reported to be privately donating to relief efforts and are following the impact of the hurricane closely.\n\nBy midday, winds howled in the Jamaica's capital, turning the sea into churning whitecaps as Beryl's eye scraped by the island's southern coast.\n\nPreviously, it was named the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic and peaked at winds of 165 mph earlier this week.\n\nAfter making landfall on the Grenadines, the storm left behind a path of \"immense destruction, pain (and) suffering\", Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves said.\n\nThree people were reported to have died in Grenada and Carriacou and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officials said.\n\nAnother two deaths were reported in northern Venezuela, bringing the death toll to six.\n\n\"The situation is grim,\" Grenadian Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said. \"There is no power, and there is almost complete destruction of homes and buildings on the island.\n\n\"The roads are not passable, and in many instances they are cut off because of the large quantity of debris strewn all over the streets.\"\n\nMitchell added: \"The possibility that there may be more fatalities remains a grim reality as movement is still highly restricted.\"\n\nBeryl's rapidly intensifying strength and early arrival are rare for the Atlantic hurricane season and are a troubling indicator that this season will be far from normal.\n\nThe storm has already shattered numerous records. On Sunday it became the earliest major hurricane - defined as one that is Category 3 or higher - in the Atlantic in 58 years and the only one to reach Category 4 status in the month of June.\n\nThe hurricane was able to churn to life because the ocean is as warm now as it would normally be at the peak of hurricane season, said Jim Kossin, a hurricane expert and science advisor at the nonprofit First Street Foundation.\n\n\"Hurricanes don't know what month it is, they only know what their ambient environment is,\" Mr Kossin said. \"Beryl is breaking records for the month of June because Beryl thinks it's September.\"\n\nMr Kossin added the ocean heat fueling Beryl's unprecedented strengthening \"certainly have a human fingerprint on them\".\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts the 2024 hurricane season is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.", {"uri": "8208590075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "23:23:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T23:23:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T23:22:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/hurricane-beryl-hammers-jamaica-on-path-to-caymans-mexico/article_ec1425f1-cae7-50d0-b3ac-02f8859a3c22.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl hammers Jamaica on path to Caymans, Mexico", "body": "Powerful Hurricane Beryl churned along Jamaica's southern coast on Wednesday, battering the island with dangerous winds and sea surge after leaving a trail of destruction and at least seven people dead in the Caribbean.\n\nThe eye of the Category 4 hurricane has not yet breached the shore of Jamaica but could in the coming hours, and is expected to approach or even make landfall in the Cayman islands overnight before moving onward to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, the US National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThe storm is the first since NHC records began to reach the Category 4 level in June and the earliest to reach Category 5 in July.\n\nAhead of Beryl's arrival, people across Jamaica removed boats from the water and rushed to buy food, water, gasoline and other essentials.\n\nAs of Wednesday afternoon the storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 kph), said the NHC. Hurricane conditions are spreading through the island, it said.\n\nPrime Minister Andrew Holness declared a curfew from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm across the island of 2.8 million and urged Jamaicans to comply with evacuation orders.\n\n\"If you live in a low lying area, an area historically prone to flooding and landslide or if you live on the banks of a river, I implore you to evacuate to a shelter, or to safer ground,\" he said in a video posted to social media.\n\nDesmon Brown, manager of the National Stadium in Kingston, said his staff has scrambled to be ready.\n\n\"We've taped up our windows, covered our equipment -- including computers, printers and that sort of thing. Apart from that, it's mainly concrete so there's not much we can do,\" Brown told the Jamaica Observer newspaper.\n\nMexican officials were meanwhile scrambling to prepare for Beryl, which is expected to hit somewhere between the well-known tourist hotspot of Tulum and the town of Felipe Carrillo Puerto, according to Civil Protection national coordinator Laura Velazquez.\n\nBeginning Thursday \"we will have intense rains and wind gusts\" she said, announcing the deployment of hundreds of military personnel, marines and electricity workers in anticipation of damage.\n\nThe government has prepared 112 shelters with a capacity for some 20,000 people and suspended school in the state of Quintana Roo where Beryl will hit.\n\nMore from this section Quenneville among three reinstated by NHL after 2021 bans Democratic Congressman Calls On Biden To Withdraw From Presidential Race Tattoo Inks Can Be Contaminated With Bacteria: Study - 'No communication' -\n\nBeryl has already left a trail of death with at least three people killed in Grenada, where the storm made landfall Monday, as well as one in St Vincent and the Grenadines and three in Venezuela.\n\nGrenada's Prime Minister Dickon Mitchell said the island of Carriacou, which was struck by the eye of the storm, has been all but cut off, with houses, telecommunications and fuel facilities there flattened.\n\nThe 13.5-square mile (35-square kilometer) island is home to around 9,000 people. At least two people there died, Mitchell said, with a third killed on the country's main island of Grenada when a tree fell on a house.\n\nIn St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one person on the island of Bequia was reported dead from the storm, while a man died in Venezuela's northeastern coastal state of Sucre when he was swept away by a flooded river, officials there said.\n\n- Climate change -\n\nIt is extremely rare for such a powerful storm to form this early in the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from early June to late November.\n\nWarm ocean temperatures are key for hurricanes, and North Atlantic waters are currently between two and five degrees Fahrenheit (1-3 degrees Celsius) warmer than normal, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nUN climate chief Simon Stiell, who has family on the island of Carriacou, said climate change was \"pushing disasters to record-breaking new levels of destruction.\"\n\n\"Disasters on a scale that used to be the stuff of science fiction are becoming meteorological facts, and the climate crisis is the chief culprit,\" he said Monday, reporting that his parents' property was The wire service noted that the death toll is anticipated to rise as communication throughout the island nation is restored.\n\nMore: Hurricane Beryl delivers strong winds, heavy rain to Cayman Islands: Live updates\n\nMass destruction was reported across many Caribbean islands. At least three Windward Islands reported more than 90% of the homes and buildings were either destroyed or severely damaged, the Caribbean Disaster Emergency Management Agency reported Wednesday.\n\nWith the hurricane's new path forecasted to approach Texas, at least one county issued a voluntary evacuation notice. Cameron County, Texas residents in RVs and trailers or camping at county parks are advised to evacuate or take precautionary measures to prevent damage and injury from high winds.\n\nThe storm became the earliest recorded Category 5 hurricane ever surpassing the previous record by more than two weeks. The record was previously held by Hurricane Emily which arrived on July 17, 2005.\n\nHurricane Beryl path tracker\n\nThis forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nHurricane Beryl spaghetti models\n\nIllustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest-performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nAtlantic storm tracker\n\nContributing: Anthony Robledo, Gabe Hauari, Susan Miller, John Bacon, Jorge L. {"uri": "2024-07-411480825", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "16:20:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T16:20:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T15:30:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.cntraveller.com/article/is-it-safe-to-travel-to-the-caribbean", "title": "Is it safe to travel to the Caribbean?", "body": "As the Atlantic's earliest-ever category five hurricane causes destruction in the region, this is everything we know about travelling to the area right now\n\nA category four storm - known as Hurricane Beryl - has made landfall in the Caribbean and has been causing destruction in the area since Monday 1 July. Hurricane Beryl first made landfall in Grenada, and has since passed through Jamaica. This is everything you need to know about what's happening in the Caribbean right now, if it's safe to travel there and whether you should cancel your holiday.\n\nWhat is happening during Hurricane Beryl in the Caribbean?\n\nAt the time of writing (Thursday 4 July), Hurricane Beryl is a category three storm. Before today, it was classed as a category five (the strongest category on the scale) and category four storm, which means experts predicted catastrophic damage to buildings and significant power damage. After Hurricane Beryl made landfall in Carriacou, Grenada, the storm passed through Jamaica on the evening of Wednesday 3 July. An island-wide overnight curfew was enacted, and a flash flood warning is currently in place. Several deaths have been reported.\n\nWhere is Hurricane Beryl currently?\n\nAt the time of writing (Thursday 4 July), the hurricane is passing south of the Cayman Islands.\n\nWhere is the path of the hurricane heading?\n\nHurricane Beryl is expected to travel from the Cayman Islands towards Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula and Belize on Thursday 4 July. From there, it is expected that the hurricane will be downgraded to a tropical storm before it emerges in the Gulf of Mexico. If Hurricane Beryl retains its strength, it could hit parts of the US, such as Louisiana and Texas.\n\nIs it safe to travel to the Caribbean?\n\nThere's little official blanket advice on travel to the Caribbean at the moment. The gov.uk website urges travellers to \"follow and monitor local and international weather updates from the US National Hurricane Center and follow the advice of local authorities, including any evacuation orders.\"\n\nAirlines such as American Airlines, JetBlue and Virgin Atlantic are permitting customers who have booked travel to some affected regions the option of rescheduling their trip further into July - this will likely change as the situation progresses, so we advise contacting your airline directly.\n\nIf your trip isn't scheduled until later in the year, consider all the options before cancelling. \"It rarely makes sense to travel into a disaster zone in the immediate aftermath of a crisis,\" Juliet Kinsman wrote after the Morocco earthquake of 2023. However, tourism is a significant source of revenue for many places impacted by Hurricane Beryl - consider if it's possible to postpone a trip rather than cancel it completely.\n\nWhat about travellers currently in affected areas of the Caribbean?\n\nWhile some flights to and from affected areas, including Virgin Atlantic flights to Jamaica, have been grounded over the past few days, these are expected to resume as the hurricane moves out of these regions. Travellers have been told to follow the advice of local authorities by sheltering in place when instructed to, and have had their hotel stays extended to allow them to remain inside safely.",
